revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-27 16:38:23.000000000', 'message': "Remove use of len for testing truth

In Python a sequence or mapping that is empty has a truth value of
False, otherwise they are True. This means that:

for empty mappings and sequences
    if len(var1) == 0:
can be written as
    if not var1:

and for mappings and sequences with values:
    if len(var1) != 0
can be written as
    if var1:

This commit removes the use of len in this way. This makes the code
more 'pythonic' and improves readability and consistency.

A hacking check forms part of this commit to prevent regression. If for
some reason the len test is required the line can be marked as noqa to
so that line is skipped for that test.

Change-Id: I8978d8f5d815fdc711f26a14b5d227dc5d28618e
"}, {'created': '2015-02-04 09:09:06.000000000', 'message': "Remove use of len for testing truth

In Python a sequence or mapping that is empty has a truth value of
False, otherwise they are True. This means that:

for empty mappings and sequences
    if len(var1) == 0:
can be written as
    if not var1:

and for mappings and sequences with values:
    if len(var1) != 0
can be written as
    if var1:

This commit removes the use of len in this way. This makes the code
more 'pythonic' and improves readability and consistency.

A hacking check forms part of this commit to prevent regression. If for
some reason the len test is required the line can be marked as noqa to
so that line is skipped for that test.

Change-Id: I8978d8f5d815fdc711f26a14b5d227dc5d28618e
"}]
commit_message:
Remove use of len for testing truth

In Python a sequence or mapping that is empty has a truth value of
False, otherwise they are True. This means that:

for empty mappings and sequences
    if len(var1) == 0:
can be written as
    if not var1:

and for mappings and sequences with values:
    if len(var1) != 0
can be written as
    if var1:

This commit removes the use of len in this way. This makes the code
more 'pythonic' and improves readability and consistency.

A hacking check forms part of this commit to prevent regression. If for
some reason the len test is required the line can be marked as noqa to
so that line is skipped for that test.

Change-Id: I8978d8f5d815fdc711f26a14b5d227dc5d28618e

commit_message:
remove enable-cinder checkobox

There is "Enable Cinder" checkbox on the VMware tab in Fuel UI. It mean
that this vCenter should be used as backend for cinder-vmware. But in
Fuel 6.1 only one vCenter accessed and special checkbox totally useless

Therefore I offer very simple logik: if you want have cinder with vmdk
backend, assign cinder-vmware role to any node. Do nothing in opposite
case.

Change-Id: I35d01f892a28075cdd37ac684d68cfc89b40a41e
Implements: blueprint cinder-vmdk-role
Closes-bug: 1435725

(2 comments)

As before with chassis discovery, I'm against putting end user scripts to ./tools (which is for _development_ tools). Whatever you put into ./tools is of no use for users of distributions (like ours). I suggest adding this functionality to the client directly, i.e. for --configdrive argument to support directories."}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2015-03-23 09:44:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)

@Julia thanks for pointing out the IPA code, yeah it's hardcoded on 64MB there :( But, since the configdrive can be bigger than 64MB is generated by nova with the "iso9660" format, I think this is a bug in IPA. The configdrive will be 64MB only if it's using the "vfat" format which not the default. So I opened a bug against IPA here:https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1435237

@Dmitry, hmm yeah it makes me think, I don't have a strong argument against putting in the client, but I find it a bit weird to have the client to generate an image.
Since we only need to generate a configdrive if Ironic is being used without Nova, I thought that putting it under tools/ would make sense.

But anyway let's see what other people think about it.'}, {'account_id': 7711, 'date': '2015-03-23 10:10:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2015-03-23 10:22:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2015-03-23 10:39:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> Since we only need to generate a configdrive if Ironic is being used without Nova, I thought that putting it under tools/ would make sense

I don't get the argument. No matter how Ironic is used, scripts under ./tools are only usable for those installing Ironic from source. E.g. we (at RH) and out customers will have to reimplement it (or git clone Ironic and setup the environment).

Also, even if we leave it a script, please create a new dir (contrib?). ./tools is for _dev_ tools"}, {'account_id': 3099, 'date': '2015-03-23 20:13:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Lucas, great documentation!

I think the script is a good example that others may find useful (either directly, or as a reference for their own tool).

@Dmitry, I don't find it a big deal that someone may need to clone the repo to get to this script. They do not need to run setup on the package to use it (it should work standalone without Ironic installed), and it is not required to run Ironic, so the fact that it won't be packaged in distros isn't a problem, AFAIC. It's mainly for reference, as I understand it.

But you are correct that I don't think 'tools' is the right place for it. Perhaps 'examples' or 'contrib' directory, as you suggested.

Voting +1 to allow for more discussion."}, {'account_id': 8106, 'date': '2015-03-24 07:21:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)

Hi Lucas,

Thank you for this patch, left some concern inline, others looks fine.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2015-03-24 09:46:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)

Thanks for the comments folks,

Right I will add the script under contrib/ until we have a resolution whether leave it there or put on the client'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2015-03-24 09:53:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-24 10:30:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified+1

Just noting that we should document two things that were discussed in the IRC:

1) This change works only on images having cloud-init >= 0.7.5
2) The data sources should be set appropriately enabling ConfigDrive.  If we build through dib, it should be:
DIB_CLOUD_INIT_DATASOURCES="ConfigDrive, OpenStack" /opt/stack/diskimage-builder/bin/disk-image-create -o ubuntu-cloud-image ubuntu grub2 baremetal'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2015-03-30 13:43:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Workflow-1

commit_message:
Add config drive documentation

This patch is documenting how to enable and to access the configuration
drive when deploying instances with Ironic.

Implements: blueprint expose-configdrive
Change-Id: I2cced6d188e46dc50602acedfdc02136f8df8748

Hi John, thanks for your patch, but I don't know why we should change to autospec=True everywhere. It is used when you want to assert that a method was called on a specific object, as it requires the signature to be the same and self is passed to the method explicitly. But here you just pass mock.ANY in place of self argument. It should be used, but only when you need it I think. Please refer to the docs about this: http://www.voidspace.org.uk/python/mock/examples.html?highlight=autospec#mocking-unbound-methods"}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2015-03-31 11:45:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2015-03-31 12:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Oh, so you mean here that you can not call non-existing methods on mock, removing -1'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2015-03-31 19:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck

See if IBM xCAT error occurs again.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-31 20:15:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Top level unit tests: Use autospec=True for mocks

For the mocks use autospec=True.  This will help to catch errors when
using incorrect assertion tests.

Fix errors in tests that were discovered by changing to using
autospec=True

Use iter() around lists in side_effects as Mock has a bug when using
autospec=True.  The Python 3.x bug: http://bugs.python.org/issue17826

Change-Id: Ie95aab4a007d6cae4590178b4eb99a1baf7ca0e7

commit_message:
Add authenticate method in sdk module

This method will do authentication based on user credential provided.
If succeed, a valid token_id will be return, otherwise, an exception
will be raised.

Change-Id: I0541433604ffae29b2f25d8aa7107c51a340423b

commit_message:
Handle error message from task that failed on master

Some pre/post deployment hooks can be executed on master
node, therefore we need correctly handle response

Change-Id: I398aea770ec8d12b07e091442f6258b07d20ffca
Closes-Bug: 1430725

[{'created': '2015-04-01 20:36:11.000000000', 'message': 'Fix intermittent unit test failures

The following tests have been failing recently:

 test_update_add_locations_status_exception
 test_update_replace_duplicate_locations
 test_update_replace_locations_status_exception

They were querying storeurl.com which redirected to
www.hugedomains.com, and unexpected exchanges, eg:

 HTTP/1.1 302 Found.
 Cache-Control: private.
 Content-Length: 183.
 Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8.
 Date: Wed, 01 Apr 2015 19:05:15 GMT.
 Location: http://www.hugedomains.com/domain_profile.cfm?d=storeurl&e=com.
 Server: Microsoft-IIS/8.0.
 X-Powered-By: ASP.NET.
 Connection: keep-alive.

Mocking out the get_size function prevents these real connections.

Change-Id: Ia5d867f98ac60479c70362b0477c2a0571ac6e4f
Closes-bug: 1437346
'}]
commit_message:
Fix intermittent unit test failures

The following tests have been failing recently:

 test_update_add_locations_status_exception
 test_update_replace_duplicate_locations
 test_update_replace_locations_status_exception

They were querying storeurl.com which redirected to
www.hugedomains.com, and unexpected exchanges, eg:

 HTTP/1.1 302 Found.
 Cache-Control: private.
 Content-Length: 183.
 Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8.
 Date: Wed, 01 Apr 2015 19:05:15 GMT.
 Location: http://www.hugedomains.com/domain_profile.cfm?d=storeurl&e=com.
 Server: Microsoft-IIS/8.0.
 X-Powered-By: ASP.NET.
 Connection: keep-alive.

Mocking out the get_size function prevents these real connections.

Change-Id: Ia5d867f98ac60479c70362b0477c2a0571ac6e4f
Closes-bug: 1437346

commit_message:
Add "suspend and resume" scenario for Nova

This scenario covers cerate a server, suspend,
resume and then delete server

Change-Id: I22dd2bd4d148bc727dc30a3703211043526b9b47

Line 255.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2014-12-25 17:27:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I can understand what prompted this effort in the first place, but I still don't think this buys us much more encapsulation; encapsulation comes handy if you ever intend to replace the internals by keeping the interface intact. Here I can hardly see the case, and this method is just too small in importance to be deemed worth the use and, furthermore discovered by other developers...so I can only see a merge headache and a stream of follow-up patches in case reviews miss the adoption of the util method."}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2015-01-21 06:16:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I'd be willing to support this.  I started something similar here [1] not having come across this patch yet (there are too many patches to keep up with).  +1 for now because it is late and I have not had time to do a good review of this code.

In my specific case, I was moving the FLOATING_IP_CIDR_SUFFIX as part of refactoring and thought I could more clearly express the intent of the code without the constant while I was at it.

In general, I don't like seeing string operations doing things with IP addresses.  They don't read in a straight-forward way, they make too many assumptions about the validity of the inputs, etc, etc.  I think encapsulating details like these is an overall win.

This may not be the highest priority for the Neutron project.  In my case, my patch was a tiny bit of opportunistic work.  I was touching the code anyway and thought I could make it a little bit better in the process.

 [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/147972/"}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-02-24 22:37:45.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-12-24 16:29:35.000000000', 'message': 'Define get_cidr helper function

commit_message:
Define get_cidr helper function

The pattern "'%s/%s' % (ip, prefixlen)" is used in multiple places to
compute an ip cidr from an ip and a prefixlen. This change defines the
get_cidr function to avoid such code duplication.

Change-Id: I2d2824e32008f634012fd8bf38e104948f174d95

commit_message:
Define extract_prefixlen helper function

The pattern "ip_cidr.split('/')[1]" is used in multiple places to
extract the prefixlen from an ip_cidr. This change defines the
extract_prefixlen function to avoid such code duplication.

Change-Id: I1289b379081e0a253be8d8cb6ee911e104132f9f

Closes-bug: #1436648

commit_message:
Use 'identity_uri' to configure admin URI for kilo

Configuring admin URI using auth fragments, this is deprecated,
use 'identity_uri' instead.

Change-Id: Iba126a6ba3d2729abb845ddea81ce39221981f3f
Closes-bug: #1436648

(1 comment)

This patch series may have negligible marginal value, but I think there is value nonetheless.  I would prefer to define how a given logical operation is performed once and be able to name it rather than littering its form all over the codebase.

That said, this is proving more contentious than I anticipated, and maybe the mailing list is the place to look for consensus.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-02-24 22:38:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Define extract_ip helper function

The pattern "ip_cidr.split('/')[0]" is used in multiple places to
extract the ip part from an ip_cidr. This change defines the extract_ip
function to avoid such code duplication.

Change-Id: I19ac31c6e2b96305173f243ddcef0beff90793e1

commit_message:
Delete nodes in batch instead of iterating

Nodes were deleted by getting them from database, then iterating over
them, which was not efficient. Now they are deleted in batch.

Node model has a new method: delete_by_ids, which does just that.

Change-Id: Icc1fe51ebf31f153fe0b6302953060c5f2d7267c
Closes-Bug: #1429014

Nice catch Sam, seems like I'm having the exact same issue in the new angular tables."}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2015-04-01 22:26:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

question about methodology?'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2015-04-01 22:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Tried my suggestion and it works fine.'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2015-04-01 22:41:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That works fine for this specific case because it is a hex string, and what you've described is what my original solution was, however I was unhappy with the fact that it was assuming the string was hex thus limiting the reusability of the parser for other uuids if we needed it, and that if the uuid was to ever be changed to display in the dash separated format we would have to remember to also change the parser. The reason its as complicated as it is, is so that it should provide a valid result for any ascii string in that field."}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2015-04-02 00:39:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

you're right, the RFC supports a wider set of formats. This seems reasonable as the hyphens still have a character value. commit_message:
Fix sort order for User IDs in identity table

The order that the user IDs are sorted into by the default tablesorter
parsers is incorrect, and seems to be getting confused by the
complexity of the values in these fields. This patch adds a new
custom parser that performs some logic to normalize these values
correctly and in a way that returns the correct sorted order.

Change-Id: I62f91ff4ca4e9110d7db5b66cdbf4b3ea15105c6
Closes-Bug: 1438818

commit_message:
Replaces the screenshots and text for PXE setup

Since PXE Setup now contains only DHCP settings portion,
the screenshots and the text should be updated to reflect
changes for 6.0.

Change-Id: I693ac4b90ceee139b7d88ca44b2f6c762b5712dd
Closes-Bug: 1413816
(cherry picked from commit 2e466a53760c388b35b261066321405b3dc1d3a1)

The 'fuel nodes' command output is incorrect

The command output, present in ref arch guide,
is incorrect: several columns lack and no
description for 'group_id' is present.

This commit fixes the problem.

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-20 16:00:20.000000000', 'message': 'Switch virtualbox script to 82540EM adapter driver

With the PCnet-FAST III network adapter driver Centos 6.5 nodes
in environments get isolated via the management network and that
completely breaks the virtualbox script users experience.

The solution it to switch back to Intel PRO/1000 MT 82540EM
as it shows no issues with the connectivity.

DocImpact: Virtualbox guide

Closes-bug: #1433593

Change-Id: I33ae3cccd6f36723200cff0ff73ba0d12814fd3e
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
'}, {'created': '2015-03-20 16:21:24.000000000', 'message': 'Switch virtualbox script to 82540EM adapter driver

With the PCnet-FAST III network adapter driver Centos 6.5 nodes
in environments get isolated via the management network and that
completely breaks the virtualbox script users experience.

The solution it to switch back to Intel PRO/1000 MT 82540EM
as it shows no issues with the connectivity.

DocImpact: Virtualbox guide

Closes-bug: #1434610

Change-Id: I33ae3cccd6f36723200cff0ff73ba0d12814fd3e
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Switch virtualbox script to 82540EM adapter driver

With the PCnet-FAST III network adapter driver Centos 6.5 nodes
in environments get isolated via the management network and that
completely breaks the virtualbox script users experience.

The solution it to switch back to Intel PRO/1000 MT 82540EM
as it shows no issues with the connectivity.

DocImpact: Virtualbox guide

Closes-bug: #1434610

Change-Id: I33ae3cccd6f36723200cff0ff73ba0d12814fd3e
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

I wonder if we could just store a per pool counter  similar fieldin our the db which each allocation will have to update as part of its transaction in order for it to be successful. (4 comments)

I just realized we may have some issues to deal with around the allow_overlapping_ips flag.  If it is False, we have to ensure uniqueness of CIDR's on a per-network basis, not just per-pool (if not allowed in the pool). (2 comments)

No, changes to add subnetpools and the corresponding changes to subnets are not implemented as extensions. Yes, this is by design and was agreed upon in the spec.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2015-03-30 05:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 59:

(1 comment)

Please see the inline comments.
I was not part of the discussion regarding where this code should reside. I just think that it has consequences regarding the API and how systems interact with Neutron.
As a project I do not think that we have come to a consensus on how to deal with this.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2015-03-30 05:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 59:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2015-03-30 13:17:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 59: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Minor comments inline.
I have no strong opposition to this patch. Usage of subnetpools is entirely optional and backward compatible.

However, since Gary has raised a fundamental concern about this API change, it would be good to ensure he's ok with it before approving this patch."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2015-03-30 15:40:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 59: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I would like to response to the discussion of extension or core resource first.
Personally I would like to see some extension definition for the subnet pool so that users can know the subnet pool API is available. Otherwise users need to assume the subnet pool API is not available or need to try subnet pool API and check an response to check the subnet pool API is avail. The implementation itself is not directly related to the discussion.

For other points, I am reviewing now.'}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2015-03-30 16:00:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 59:

(4 comments)

I will spin another patch set as there is some good feedback that should be addressed.

On the issue of core vs. extension, I would point out that this is all laid out in the spec.  Why are we just now having this conversation? Certain details included in specs such as DB schema can be considered implementation details and be subject to some change as we implement and de-scope. However, core vs. extension does not fall in that category in my opinion.  Do specs mean nothing? We've already discussed this and the blueprint was approved. It's a little frustrating that this is coming up the day before we lock down FFE's."}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2015-03-30 16:08:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 59: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2015-03-30 16:36:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 59:

(4 comments)

I would like not to put -1 only to you. I agree it is our fault during reviewing the spec. In theory, Core API change without a way to detect it should be avoided.

Core vs extension approach and opt-in vs opt-out approach are different. They are not orthogonal. In general, we use extension and opt-in approach so far. I think this implementation decided to change the core API as the author would like to change the common feature which can be used by all plugins/drivers. It itself sounds reasonable.

What I concern is only from the API perspective without a way to know the change.
IMHO it is good to provide a shim extension which cannot be opt-out and only available through the API (ext-list). There is another concern. Not all plugins consume db_base plugin and this change may break them at this moment of the dev cycle.

If the Neutron community decides to change the core API without providing a way to detect available features, I will follow it. I believe it makes difficult to detect at least Horizon integration (I will give -1 in Horizon if the implementation assume some version of Horizon implicitly and it requires a dirty work around). Another negative impact is that it makes difficult to evolve subnet pool API itself and it means the subnet pool API should be backward compatible until a new API version is coming.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2015-03-30 16:36:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 59:

Can we discuss our approach at today's Neutron team meeting?"}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2015-03-30 18:03:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 60.'}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2015-03-30 18:11:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 59:

'}, {'created': '2015-03-15 23:43:49.000000000', 'message': 'Subnet allocation from a subnet pool

Contains API changes, model changes, and logic required to enable a subnet to
be allocated from a subnet pool. Users can request a subnet allocation by
supplying subnetpool_id and optionally prefixlen or cidr. If cidr is
specified, an attempt is made to allocate the given CIDR from the pool. If
prefixlen is specified, and attempt is made to allocate any CIDR with the
given prefix length from the pool. If neither is specified, a CIDR is chosen
from the pool using the default prefix length for the pool.

ApiImpact
Partially-Implements: blueprint subnet-allocation
Change-Id: I59a221f4f434718fb77bd132dbbe1ff50fce4b0c

commit_message:
Subnet allocation from a subnet pool

Contains API changes, model changes, and logic required to enable a subnet to
be allocated from a subnet pool. Users can request a subnet allocation by
supplying subnetpool_id and optionally prefixlen or cidr. If cidr is
specified, an attempt is made to allocate the given CIDR from the pool. If
prefixlen is specified, an attempt is made to allocate any CIDR with the
given prefix length from the pool. If neither is specified, a CIDR is chosen
from the pool using the default prefix length for the pool.

ApiImpact
Partially-Implements: blueprint subnet-allocation
Change-Id: I59a221f4f434718fb77bd132dbbe1ff50fce4b0c

commit_message:
Simplify retargetable test framework

The retargetable testing prototype previously relied on each test case
defining the 'scenarios' attribute used to parametize testing with
testscenarios.  Anticipating the requirement to retrofit the imported
tempest api test cases, this change moves scenario definition to a
base class since scenarios are common across all api tests.

This change also sets the retargetable test to skip when invoked
against rest.  Tempest uses class-level setup for auth and this needs
to be broken out into fixtures before the retargetable testing will
work again.

Change-Id: I70eb21db9b983d45e9bcc7ea90e36f202d3e3e45

* Reduce dead_retry from 300 to 30. When 3 servers lost memcached server
  and detect it differently so the divergence of hash function is 5
  minutes.
* Decrease socket_timeout from 3 seconds to 1 second to detect lost backend
  faster
* Increase pool size from 100 to 1000 connections.

commit_message:
Tune keystone settings to fail-over faster

* Reduce dead_retry from 300 to 30. When 3 servers lost memcached server
  and detect it differently so the divergence of hash function is 5
  minutes.
* Decrease socket_timeout from 3 seconds to 1 second to detect lost backend
  faster
* Increase pool size from 100 to 1000 connections.

Closes-Bug: 1432242

Change-Id: Ib16a9cba4de8442afa2b78770cb93f561b0fd37e
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>

Vagrant box definition

This is a copy of
https://github.com/CGenie/vagrant-fuel-dev
with some fixes and adjustments.

Change-Id: I3e74df74c4d05c0418efbaa1cdd7b767b45e35f1

commit_message:
Fix error raising in security groups method

In case there were security groups not belonging to tenant on port
_get_security_groups_on_port would try to raise exception but fail
trying to index set.

This patch simply joins the whole set as a string and inserts it
into the standard SecurityGroupNotFound exception.

No new exception types, no string freeze violations.

Co-Author: watanabe.isao <zou.yun@jp.fujitsu.com>
Co-Author: Jacek Swiderski <jacek.swiderski@codilime.com>

Change-Id: I039ea57269dc53ced8dece0985f33ce9ae7eab17
Closes-Bug: #1373816

I've been trying to figure out why this change bothers me, and I think it's that it addresses a symptom and not a problem.  Yes, cores have special powers.  Yes, they're different by definition.  You can call them maintainers, or supreme overlords, or janitors, or watermelonheads, and it won't change that fundamental fact. And most projects have a heirarchy of workers, and no one in the heirarchy is unimportant. What, exactly, is going on with neutron that part of the team is feeling left out/disenfranchised? And how can we address *that*? Because this proposed change doesn't change whatever that core issue is (pun really not intended.)"}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2015-03-24 09:53:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I am fan of moving to the maintainers model (which eventually means having submaintainers just like MAINTAINERS files contain in any large project -- that uses that system)"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-03-24 21:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think that unilaterally changing how core reviewers are named in various project teams would create a lot of confusion, and would rather have a single way of calling them across "OpenStack projects".

See corresponding governance patch discussion @ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/163660/'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-03-25 14:20:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

Thanks for all the comments folks! I think ultimately I'm happy to drive this discussion n Neutron (and wow, talk about a lot of people reviewing your patch, this is a new record!). Ultimately, I'd like all of OpenStack to move to a MAINTERS model, similar to the kernel. But in Neutron, this makes even more sense. We already have multiple repositories (soon to be more), so having a MAINTAINER system makes a lot of sense. I'm going to re-propose a series of patches which get us there for Liberty.

Thanks for all the feedback!"}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2015-03-25 16:08:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-03-26 20:26:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-03-26 20:27:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

In the latest patchset, I've addressed the concerns raised in the first one. I've also started us down the path of having submaintainer teams, with the logically existing ones clearly called out for now."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2015-03-26 21:20:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Interesting, but most of the text needs some love around the area of dealing with five separate teams and how those interact.  The voting and stats blocks treat them as one, whereas the merge rights are separate, e.g.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-26 22:02:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

- gate-neutron-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/08/164208/3/check/gate-neutron-docs/d3f940a//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 23s'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2015-03-27 09:04:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I think there is a key difference between "core reviewers" and "maintainers". In Linux kernel world (as in Oslo libraries world), maintainers are specific individuals responsible for specific sections of code. It's the go-to person and final decision point for a subsection of code. There needs to only be one for a given subsection of code. So it's like a PTL delegation to key individuals, not like a subteam that happens to have +2 review rights.

I'm totally fine with using "maintainers" the way they are used in Linux and Oslo to designate the sub-PTLs that look after a specific subsection of code within a project team. So if you designate a maintainer for neutron-lbaas, that person becomes a "maintainer".

I don't think it's a good idea to rename "core reviewers" to "maintainers", since that dilutes the meaning of maintainers. It also reinforces the "class" aspect where we want to reinforce the "duty" aspect.

It's still unclear to me what value you get from such a change, too. If it's just about giving reviewers a more rewarding name, I really don't think we need to add benefits to being a core reviewer. It's already incentivized enough by companies to pervert the system. If it's about recognizing a broader leadership team within Neutron by giving them a title, then I'd argue it should be disjoint from core reviewing. You can have leaders in Neutron that won't commit to do enough reviewing to be a core reviewer (think: someone handling bug scrubbing end-to-end).'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2015-03-27 12:51:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Agree with Thierry ... further, I really want to avoid even worse confusion through OpenStack with different projects adopting very different terminology.  Let's please try to handle this consistently.

In fact, the TC just shot down such a terminology change here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/163660/"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-03-27 13:00:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2015-03-27 13:05:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(9 comments)

You're proposing a completely new role, described by a set of responsibilities (maintain the project quality through fixing bugs, writing tests, writing documentation, and mentoring new contributors) which are not representable in gerrit. While I think these are all good values to have and good activities to recognize, they are not actually related to the gerrit ACL. So I dont understand why you are proposing to also remove the term "core reviewer" and conflate these two things as one. Nor are these activities or values related to "maintaining" a stable code base, so I do not understand why you've chosen this word to describe this set of activities.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-03-27 13:44:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

There are two key points with this patch:

1. Move away from the term "core reviewer", which places a super-power like ability on people, and move towards using the term "maintainer", which is less sexy and actually indicates what people with the role do. I'm surprised to see some veteran OpenStack people who fail to see that being a "core reviewer/maintainer" is more than just merging patches.

2. Move to a maintainer model. We've been doing this already, this patch is just calling that out.

While I could propose two patches, I've rolled the above two items into a single patch.

Further, as Russell and Joe have indicated, trying to make this sort of change across OpenStack will fail and bog down in the politics. Thus, we're doing it from the bottom up starting with Neutron. Hopefully other projects will see the value of moving away from the term "core reviewer", which only seems to indicate those reviewers have special powers, and towards maintainer, which is what the core reviewers are doing.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-03-27 15:18:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)

While I am very interested in this and like the direction its going in. I am dropping my +1 (from the previous version), because I do not work on neutron and after further thought don't feel that I really should be weighing in with a +/-1 on a internal neutron matter.


As for the consistency argument, as the 'tent' grows consistency gets harder and harder (when do we start allowing other languages in etc.). And I find it odd that we want to prevent projects from experimenting like this in the name of consistency, I am not sure what the alternative is."}, {'account_id': 4656, 'date': '2015-03-27 15:35:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

It is just semantics, but I think that there are lots of people in the community who are important to the project, who may not be core due to many factors. Perhaps changing the name for "the people who merge other people's code" we can help balance things out and shrink the gap between core vs. non-core.'}, {'account_id': 11343, 'date': '2015-03-27 15:52:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2015-03-27 16:05:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I guess "veterans" remember that we decided very early on in this project to not create classes of developers -- everyone is a dev and everyone is a reviewer. No committers or repo owners, no aristocracy. Some people just commit to do a lot of reviewing and keep current with the code, and have votes that matter more (+2).

This ideal was bastardized by various external incentives, and now it's become a developer class, a level to reach, and cleaning up core reviewers teams has become an issue (you basically have to get out of OpenStack to be removed). I see this change as making a step farther away from this ideal of a single cohesive development community, by codifying a whole new level/class/caste that developers will want to reach to get the recognition/rights/bonuses associated with it.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-03-27 16:14:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thierry, this is doing the opposite of what you're saying, if you feel it doesn't I'd like input on reworking it. The problem you're describing is what we're looking at solving here. "Core Reviewer" is implying super powers, "maintainer" is much blander. It's a basic change.

The second part of this is just putting into words what "core reviewers" are already doing.'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2015-03-27 16:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

"to not create classes of developers"

Ahh, but you did. Differing authority levels will always mean that, wishes and fairies notwithstanding.

The interesting point to me is not in trying to pretend that much harder that reality isn't reality, but rather what are the underlying root issues that got us to this patch, and how do we best address that.  Trust problem?  Personality problem? Merge velocity problem? The mistaken belief that not having +2 means your opinion doesn't matter?

Playing a perception game that we're all equal (and yet not) is missing the point, I think.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2015-03-27 16:53:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I think the effort to make responsibilities clear is good.  And I've been citing neutron as an example of effective subsystem delegation.  There is a lot here that would be good to communicate around the rest of the project.

I worry that we're getting hung up on the terminology though.  I understand the feelings of status that people attribute to the core reviewers, but when they are called maintainers, the same feelings will attach.  And then we will have to call them stewards.

Let's focus instead on the meat of this, which is that some people don't understand the duties of core reviewers -- that won't be solved by a nomenclature change.  The part of this dealing with subsystems is great -- it's fully formed and does not depend on the name change, so we should not tie them together."}, {'account_id': 4656, 'date': '2015-03-27 18:07:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> I see this change as making a step farther away from this ideal of a single cohesive development community, by codifying a whole new level/class/caste that developers will want to reach to get the recognition/rights/bonuses associated with it."

I would argue that this perception has already occurred'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2015-03-27 20:05:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

We're trying to change the nomenclature of the Neutron culture as the starting point for changing the culture itself for the better.  This effort has no bearing on any other project at this point, and negative reviews from those that aren't active contributors to the project doesn't seem reasonable to me, TC membership or no."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2015-03-27 20:05:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 287, 'date': '2015-03-28 01:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I think a change in naming such needs to be coordinated with those that will have to communicate it to the wider community, newcomers included. 

That is not just me, but also the TC, the Foundation Marketing and the Business Development roles, the Board ... I disagree that this decision only affects Neutron developers.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-03-30 16:39:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-30 16:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

@maru: I'm sorry you see it that way. The fact that OpenStack is huge is a symptom of success, something to be happy about, not sad. Communicating and changing anything to multiple thousands of people requires time and the involvement of multiple actors. It's again a sign of success, I don't see any reason to be sad about that."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2015-03-30 17:31:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Stefano: I'm not sad that OpenStack is huge.  I don't agree, though, that the success of OpenStack has been due to committee-driven standardization of culture.  Each project within the umbrella of OpenStack has unique cultures that in their own way contribute to the success of the overall effort.  I think that attempting to constrain how individual projects evolve due to some higher-level need for simplification ignores the reality that culture by its nature is messy.  Better, I think, to define expectations of outcome - respectful, cooperative and productive community - than arbitrary process and nomenclature that may end up actually interfering with achieving said goals.

Further reading: http://www.amazon.com/Seeing-like-State-Certain-Condition/dp/0300078153"}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-03-30 17:54:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-13 14:56:51.000000000', 'message': 'Change from core reviewers to maintainers

This more accurately reflects what the existing core reviewer label
was setup to convey. For one thing, in the old terminology, even
non-core reviewers are critical to the project. The only difference
between core and non-core reviewers was the ability to merge code,
which in effect is maintaining the neutron codebase. Thus, we'll
move to calling ourselves "Neutron Maintainers" now instead of
core reviewers.

Change-Id: I2628dad7ba2bbc0b63dd9ed716db6221a5b30b2d
'}, {'created': '2015-03-16 21:27:35.000000000', 'message': 'Change from core reviewers to maintainers

This more accurately reflects what the existing core reviewer label
was setup to convey. For one thing, in the old terminology, even
non-core reviewers are critical to the project. The only difference
between core and non-core reviewers was the ability to merge code,
which in effect is maintaining the neutron codebase. Thus, we'll
move to calling ourselves "Neutron Maintainers" now instead of
core reviewers.

Change-Id: I2628dad7ba2bbc0b63dd9ed716db6221a5b30b2d
'}, {'created': '2015-03-26 20:26:48.000000000', 'message': 'Change from core reviewers to maintainers

This more accurately reflects what the existing core reviewer label
was setup to convey. For one thing, in the old terminology, even
non-core reviewers are critical to the project. The only difference
between core and non-core reviewers was the ability to merge code,
which in effect is maintaining the neutron codebase. Thus, we'll
move to calling ourselves "Neutron Maintainers" now instead of
core reviewers.

This also paves the way for maintainer subteams. For now, the
logical lines for these are a base Neutron maintainer team,
Neutron FWaaS, LBaaS, and VPNaaS submaintainer teams, and a
Neutron specs submaintainer team. We'll evolve this a bit more
in Liberty as well, but this is a good starting point.

Change-Id: I2628dad7ba2bbc0b63dd9ed716db6221a5b30b2d

commit_message:
Update core reviewer responsibilities

This patch more clearly lays out who can merge code into the plethora
of Neutron repositories. It also clarifies a few things with the
existing text in places.

Change-Id: I2628dad7ba2bbc0b63dd9ed716db6221a5b30b2d

commit_message:
Move API tests to neutron.test.api

To make api test development simpler, move the tests to
neutron.tests.api.  The neutron.tests.tempest subtree will remain
while work continues to transition the required functionality to
tempest-lib.

Change-Id: Ie90671fbfe2f633e851da82728e152482133fd87

commit_message:
Restructure Ceph/Puppet params to reflect changes in puppet-ceph

A change [1] in puppet-ceph offers more flexibility but breaks
backwards so we had to update our composition layer as well; we gain
control of the cephx keyring in the template though.

1. Ie6adbd601388ab52c37037004bd0ceef9fc41942

Change-Id: Ia8196849afce2969daa608828cec81ebe3ac96e1

instance power state may be integer zero, in that case the error message would
be no correct.

BTW, this patch remove 'not_launched' from kwargs since no other code set this
parameter into kwargs.

Closes-bug: #1437111

instance power state may be integer zero, in that case the error message would
be no correct.

BTW, this patch remove 'not_launched' from kwargs since no other code set this
parameter into kwargs.

Closes-bug: 1437111
Change-Id: Id2fb561a79d627eb8c6b41e4fe3549dc69dc7d99
"}]
commit_message:
Fix incorrect http_conflict error message

instance power state may be integer zero, in that case the error message would
be no correct.

BTW, this patch remove 'not_launched' from kwargs since no other code set this
parameter into kwargs.

Closes-bug: 1437111
Change-Id: Id2fb561a79d627eb8c6b41e4fe3549dc69dc7d99

commit_message:
Improve spec for notification API

There are some changes for the design of notification API:
1. Update the REST API of subscriptions
2. Changed 'publisher' to 'subscriber'

Change-Id: Iea356e77c9b52d399a116e92a098ddb018b21188

commit_message:
Fix to raise exception by ryu

local_out_delete_port called from _repair_ofport_change fails because
port.vif_mac is None.

Related Change-Id: Ie6703a84981d95492ffb66746a34ea28fcf34ff2

Change-Id: I5fc3d063b219634a983e11a792d6930f71c261bd
Closes-Bug: #1435638

commit_message:
Add tripleo-puppet-elements to pull-tools

Now that we're using puppet elements with TripleO, it will be useful if
pull-tools can keep it up to date for us.

Change-Id: Iee97b1b0d0c6fdcee0e19dcf5910d4446ffcdb9f

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-02 06:01:16.000000000', 'message': 'Remove debugging garbage left in context

Note in this middleware oslo_log cannot be used. We have to do things
differently because context is not yet constructed, even if we do want
to log something out.

This patch removes the log import and print calls.

Change-Id: Ia93059879d306ef515ceead7facab02a6b9629e4
'}]
commit_message:
Remove debugging garbage left in context

Note in this middleware oslo_log cannot be used. We have to do things
differently because context is not yet constructed, even if we do want
to log something out.

This patch removes the log import and print calls.

Change-Id: Ia93059879d306ef515ceead7facab02a6b9629e4

code looks good to me and i like to see this merged.
-1 because i agree Armando about the process.'}, {'account_id': 6502, 'date': '2015-03-23 09:03:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

This is very useful feature that we really need right now, thank you for this patch. I'm looking forward to set +1, after creating bug for it."}, {'account_id': 14757, 'date': '2015-03-23 18:42:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

The advertise MTU feature is not a DHCP specific feature.  It is applicable to any mechanism that can advertise MTUs to a VM.  The blueprint specifically calls out IPv6 RAs as well as DHCP.  DHCP was simply the first/reference/priority implementation.  Moving this configuration option to DHCP specific code will force us to move it back (or duplicate) when we add support in l3_agent for radvd.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2015-03-24 10:39:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

In my opinion the reference implementation is really incomplete. Not only that it also breaks the API model in my opinion.
It is not clear what action the community is taking to address this.'}, {'account_id': 14757, 'date': '2015-03-24 14:04:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@garyk:  Scoping the discussion to this review, I don't see how this proposed change alleviates your concerns but it does definitely make the feature DHCP specific--which is at odds with the widely reviewed spec and implementation.  

Probably we should keep the wider discussion on the API changes and the phase of implementation that made Kilo on openstack-dev & IRC, right?

In case anyone needs the full set of references for MTU advertisement:
BP:  http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/kilo/mtu-selection-and-advertisement.html
DB:            https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153451
config files:  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153733
ML2 and OVS:   https://review.openstack.org/#/c/156318
DHCP agent:    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/155874"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-25 07:44:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2015-04-02 06:16:34.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

NCFTPG'}]

commit_message:
Move advertise_mtu to dhcp.ini file

This is only used in DHCP agent so no need for it to be defined in the
neutron configuration file. It is sufficient to be defined in the
dhcp.ini file.

Change-Id: I62b25fcc84ed82442954adc4a3a7328a0e87d947

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-31 10:16:00.000000000', 'message': 'Specify memcache_pool.Token as keystone token driver

Keystone team has a strong warning in their documentation:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/configuration.html

to use keystone.token.persistence.backends.memcache_pool.Token
instead of keystone.token.persistence.backends.memcache.Token
specifically when deploying Keystone under eventlet.

Change-Id: I674ee3440bb26af942db2859ed6f8512cbc22fee
Partial-Bug: #1405549
(cherry picked from commit ae7e0e1d3730ba8227c742efac3cd3e8b334d131)
'}]
commit_message:
Specify memcache_pool.Token as keystone token driver

Keystone team has a strong warning in their documentation:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/configuration.html

to use keystone.token.persistence.backends.memcache_pool.Token
instead of keystone.token.persistence.backends.memcache.Token
specifically when deploying Keystone under eventlet.

Change-Id: I674ee3440bb26af942db2859ed6f8512cbc22fee
Partial-Bug: #1405549
(cherry picked from commit ae7e0e1d3730ba8227c742efac3cd3e8b334d131)

commit_message:
Updating FWaaS CLI to allow router references

One or more router names or IDs can be provided
when created or updating a firewall resource.

Change-Id: I222ce8032987a821c46d43d1597a97fbc90af908
Partially implements: blueprint fwaas-router-insertion

commit_message:
Skip socket related unit tests on OSX

For now, let's skip these two tests since
SO_REUSEADDR behaves differently.

Closes-Bug: #1436895
Change-Id: I3bcd3edca2057a3990bf2cca6d2871555bd0123a

[{'created': '2015-03-16 15:52:37.000000000', 'message': 'Compute: catch more specific exception for _get_instance_nw_info

There are cases when the method _heal_instance_info_cache tries to
update the network cache. The problem here is that the instance no
longer exists. The exception handling was very broad. This adds
treatment for the specific exception.

Change-Id: I04372cec81fde6ef06e9d7f2b59c1e47e15c0905
Closes-bug: #1385246
(cherry picked from commit dd9a7e405f3cde42262a4b7e5476a0a82c8a1e7f)

commit_message:
Compute: catch more specific exception for _get_instance_nw_info

There are cases when the method _heal_instance_info_cache tries to
update the network cache. The problem here is that the instance no
longer exists. The exception handling was very broad. This adds
treatment for the specific exception.

Change-Id: I04372cec81fde6ef06e9d7f2b59c1e47e15c0905
Closes-bug: #1385246
(cherry picked from commit dd9a7e405f3cde42262a4b7e5476a0a82c8a1e7f)

commit_message:
Support macvtap for vif_type being hw_veb

This patch programs VLAN into a VF pci device, and properly
plug/unplug it into the instance.

Change-Id: I85eb3c1347d057d1f292e747f950065b8f394147
Closes-Bug: 1370348
Co-Authored-By: Itzik Brown <ItzikB@mellanox.com>
(cherry picked from commit 386e38198d63cf2dc45507ca7e4dc82f0bcd9bb9)

commit_message:
Fix update on failed stack

In the case of a dependant resource failing, a nested stack will not get
created, so we need to at least create an empty nested stack to allow
the update to work.

Change-Id: I2e83546801bce0da566ec8ef1322e30d695ff02a
Closes-bug: 1411103
(cherry picked from commit aafbf6025ca826d76f5ea6e99dfe2c2e62fe0422)

[{'created': '2015-02-06 04:05:59.000000000', 'message': 'Only run apt-get update once

We currently run apt-get update twice for no reason. Move the update to
the beginning of pre-install.d and remove the redundant update.

Change-Id: Ie98dda7d5d75848e539ea097367b5b8b07b677d9
'}]
commit_message:
Only run apt-get update once

We currently run apt-get update twice for no reason. Move the update to
the beginning of pre-install.d and remove the redundant update.

Change-Id: Ie98dda7d5d75848e539ea097367b5b8b07b677d9

commit_message:
Use declarative dib features for hot elements

DIB has support for installing packages and static files declaratively
rather than via a custom install.d script.

Change-Id: I32be0131c369417e730353d7b9c6f49069c42838

commit_message:
Add port binding database table

This change allows the user to specify an interface name for a port
and have it saved in a DB. Saving in the DB allows the interface
name to be saved across data sync operations, described in
kilo/data_sync

Change-Id: Ic18ad8a24625c4f35cfa54ba8ddf6a14fd7da634
Signed-off-by: Joe Mills <joe@midokura.com>

subject: Rename project to tenant
messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2015-04-01 11:23:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-01 11:23:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-04-01 12:08:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Long have I waited for common sense to return to the OpenStack ecosystem. All hail "tenant" as the new "tenant".

-jay'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2015-04-01 12:21:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

LOL'}, {'account_id': 113, 'date': '2015-04-01 12:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Instead of tenant, why not tenet? In code we trust.'}, {'account_id': 136, 'date': '2015-04-01 13:20:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It also saves one byte every time 'tenant' is used rather than 'project'. Maybe we should consider 'ten' ?"}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2015-04-02 04:05:22.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

It's not April 1 any more."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-01 11:23:39.000000000', 'message': 'Rename project to tenant

The term "project" is too overloaded and used too many places.
Furthermore, it implies a potential entitlement or sense of inevitable
permanance as a part of OpenStack that undercuts the ability for other
people to ignore the current work being done and do their own thing with
an eye on supplanting the people squatting on gold mine currently.

Change all governance references to "project" with the term "tenant".
Not only does "tenant" not carry any pre-conceived connotations as to
how it relates to a technical organizational structure, but it has the
added benefit of implying a temporary condition, reminding us all that
we're only here until such a time as gentrification leads to forcible
eviction.

Change-Id: I5a699cc5c406eb7f4a9cb52d9376d8ac41a4cd9c
'}]
commit_message:
Rename project to tenant

The term "project" is too overloaded and used too many places.
Furthermore, it implies a potential entitlement or sense of inevitable
permanance as a part of OpenStack that undercuts the ability for other
people to ignore the current work being done and do their own thing with
an eye on supplanting the people squatting on gold mine currently.

Change all governance references to "project" with the term "tenant".
Not only does "tenant" not carry any pre-conceived connotations as to
how it relates to a technical organizational structure, but it has the
added benefit of implying a temporary condition, reminding us all that
we're only here until such a time as gentrification leads to forcible
eviction.

Change-Id: I5a699cc5c406eb7f4a9cb52d9376d8ac41a4cd9c

commit_message:
[Launch Instance Fix] Making table expand faster

Currently, the animation is too slow to show the details in the
table's row. It looks like it to hard for the UI to do such a
simple thing. We should make it faster and slick.

Change-Id: Ia8cff5692b20c3482b06e406ca44480d02ee54a4
Closes-Bug: #1439449

commit_message:
Ignore it. My own test.
Decouple the image data from the image metadata for uploading.

When uploading the image to the glance store, we can first send the
metadata to reserve the image, then send the image data separately
via other protocols, and finally update the status of the image.

Useful for the image transfer plugin. BP needs to be registered.

Change-Id: I226ee8747ca921c9deec62e38fa0c1783c9963c5

subject: pxe deploy fails for whole disk images in UEFI

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-26 04:52:22.000000000', 'message': 'pxe deploy fails for whole disk images in UEFI

Disabling the whole disk image deploy for pxe drivers.

Reasons:-
1. syslinux do not support chain loading of bootloaders in uefi boot
   mode.
2. UEFI bootloader elilo used in ironic do not support chain loading of
   bootloaders.

Closes-Bug : 1432498

Change-Id: I187e773177c5f163094f6d963dcf7962f4895a28

Closes-Bug: 1432498

Change-Id: I187e773177c5f163094f6d963dcf7962f4895a28
"}]
commit_message:
pxe deploy fails for whole disk images in UEFI

Disabling the whole disk image deploy for pxe drivers in UEFI boot
mode if 'boot_option' is not 'local'.

Reasons:-
1. syslinux do not support chain loading of bootloaders in uefi boot
   mode.
2. UEFI bootloader elilo used in ironic do not support chain loading of
   bootloaders.

Closes-Bug: 1432498

Change-Id: I187e773177c5f163094f6d963dcf7962f4895a28

subject: Remove is_public from reserved attribute in v2

[{'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2015-02-10 23:17:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2015-02-10 23:20:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Uhm, this breaks API stability. You can' just remove a parameter like this. Please see:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/APIChangeGuidelines#Generally_Not_Acceptable"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2015-02-10 23:26:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

FWIW, this doesn't remove the property from the API, it removes it from the ones that are reserved, which means it now *allows* that property to be used by users. If anything, it opens the API a bit more, which in this particular case doesn't seem like a breaking change.

In addition, we've bumped the API version in this cycle too, so this won't break previous API versions.

I'm ok with this change."}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2015-02-10 23:44:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Ah, ok sorry I misread that. I'm still not sure changing the usage around that param like this is a backwards compatible change either, but if it's around a version boundary I guess it's ok."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-02-11 00:26:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

So while I agree with the premise that there doesn't seem to be a good reason to keep it reserved, what's the benefit of removing it from the list of reserved attributes?"}, {'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2015-02-11 10:01:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

@Ian: because logically it's not a reserved parameter and its removing from the list makes the code cleaner."}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2015-02-11 10:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

What is the behaviour if you are running both v1 and v2?

If I use v2 to mark an image with is_public True, does that change the behaviour when accessing that image via v1?'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2015-02-11 11:37:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> If I use v2 to mark an image with is_public True, does that change the behaviour when accessing that image via v1?

To answer my own question ... no. (It correctly gets interpreted as a generic property.)'}, {'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2015-02-11 12:33:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes, is_public in terms of visibility is ignored in v2 and considered as a generic property, so there is no reason to keep it in reserved attributes list, as Fei has mentioned.'}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2015-02-11 14:20:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Mike, I understand it isn't used in v2. What I'm trying to weigh here is the benefit of allowing this as a generic property versus the confusion it will cause for users familiar with v1 but not v2. I don't know, but I would hazard a guess that this was reserved to prevent confusion when updating usage from v1 to v2. Right now, code setting is_public to affect the visibility of the image in v1 will trigger a 403 error. Users will have to check the documentation and will see that the name they're looking for is visibility. With this merged, users will not see any error and will be baffled as to why their images are not being made public (or private, whichever the case may be)."}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2015-02-11 14:55:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I do see where Ian is coming from. 

a v2 image show will display the 'generic/uninterpreted property' (allowed with this patch) inline:

 +------------------+--------------------------------------+
 | Property         | Value                                |
 +------------------+--------------------------------------+
 .
 .
 .
 | is_public        | True                                 |
 .
 .
 .
 +------------------+--------------------------------------+

in the exact same way as v1 will show the 'real/interpreted' 'is_public' field:
 
 +----------------------+--------------------------------------+
 | Property             | Value                                |
 +----------------------+--------------------------------------+
 .
 .
 .
 | is_public            | False                                |
 .
 .
 .
 +----------------------+--------------------------------------+

I wonder if the potential for user confusion outweighs the 'cleaner code' benefit?"}, {'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2015-02-11 16:37:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yep, I see it too.But afaik, v1 is going to be deprecated in kilo and after this commit v1->v2 compatibility is ok (if image was created with v1 than all its properties would be exactly the same in v2).
And if someone will create images using v2, and then watch them using deprecated v1 of course it can lead to some incompatibility (very rare btw).
If it is very scary to merge it right now, let's postpone the patch to the point where v1 is completely removed from glance in the L cycle."}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2015-02-12 09:46:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I do agree, other way this would have been problem (restricting usage of previously available attribute), but cleaning up restrictions for something that has no justification is good thing. Thanks Fei.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-02-12 09:46:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2015-02-12 11:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow

Change-Id: Iba677979a2c1e8d45dcdc66394c5c9add51b7289

commit_message:
Remove is_public from reserved attribute in v2

In v2, we're using 'visibility' instead of 'is_public',
so seems there is no good reason to keep 'is_public' as
a reserved attribute.

Closes-Bug: #1420501

Change-Id: Iba677979a2c1e8d45dcdc66394c5c9add51b7289

subject: Allow sending object metadata after data
messages:
[{'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2015-04-01 18:15:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2015-04-01 19:40:59.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

cause it's on the wrong branch"}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2015-04-02 03:21:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm unable to find an equivalent on any other branch. Are you use you're re-uploading this after abandonment?"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-01 18:15:42.000000000', 'message': 'Allow sending object metadata after data

This lets the proxy server send object metadata to the object server
after the object data. This is necessary for EC, as it allows us to
compute the etag of the object in the proxy server and still store it
with the object.

The wire format is a multipart MIME document. For sanity during a
rolling upgrade, the multipart MIME document is only sent to the
object server if it indicates, via 100 Continue header, that it knows
how to consume it.

Example 1 (new proxy, new obj server):

   proxy: PUT /p/a/c/o
          X-Backend-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

     obj: 100 Continue
        X-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

   proxy: --MIMEmimeMIMEmime...

Example2: (new proxy, old obj server)

   proxy: PUT /p/a/c/o
          X-Backend-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

     obj: 100 Continue

   proxy: <obj body>

Change-Id: Id38f7e93e3473f19ff88123ae0501000ed9b2e89
'}]
commit_message:
Allow sending object metadata after data

This lets the proxy server send object metadata to the object server
after the object data. This is necessary for EC, as it allows us to
compute the etag of the object in the proxy server and still store it
with the object.

The wire format is a multipart MIME document. For sanity during a
rolling upgrade, the multipart MIME document is only sent to the
object server if it indicates, via 100 Continue header, that it knows
how to consume it.

Example 1 (new proxy, new obj server):

   proxy: PUT /p/a/c/o
          X-Backend-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

     obj: 100 Continue
        X-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

   proxy: --MIMEmimeMIMEmime...

Example2: (new proxy, old obj server)

   proxy: PUT /p/a/c/o
          X-Backend-Obj-Metadata-Footer: yes

     obj: 100 Continue

   proxy: <obj body>

Change-Id: Id38f7e93e3473f19ff88123ae0501000ed9b2e89

commit_message:
Modifying CRD return type from dict to object

- Adding warlock library and json-schema dependency
- Adding resources directory which contains cluster object schema
- Modifying unit test cases
- Changing doc content

Change-Id: I54e4ee316a8cac45ce75ea5d528211c96ef83e25

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-23 13:37:05.000000000', 'message': 'Fix common misspellings

Wikipedia's list of common misspellings [1] has a machine-readable
version.  This patch fixes those misspellings mentioned in the list
which don't have multiple right variants (as e.g. "accension", which can
be both "accession" and "ascension"), such misspellings are left
untouched.  The list of changes was manually re-checked for false
positives.

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Lists_of_common_misspellings/For_machines

Change-Id: I6f549eb78998ead9b2f1a04e196e65b3f08f1be7
Signed-off-by: Martin Kletzander <mkletzan@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix common misspellings

Wikipedia's list of common misspellings [1] has a machine-readable
version.  This patch fixes those misspellings mentioned in the list
which don't have multiple right variants (as e.g. "accension", which can
be both "accession" and "ascension"), such misspellings are left
untouched.  The list of changes was manually re-checked for false
positives.

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Lists_of_common_misspellings/For_machines

Change-Id: I6f549eb78998ead9b2f1a04e196e65b3f08f1be7
Signed-off-by: Martin Kletzander <mkletzan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-01 18:40:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix intermittent test case failure due to dict order

The test case expected output relies on the order of strings
generated from the arbitrary ordering of dictionaries.  Change
to be resilient to ordering by using assertIn on each item
instead of assertEqual on the generated list.

Change-Id: Ib4f0586a24846660aedc20517f58fa7ff0dd6cc6
Closes-Bug: 1436424
'}]
commit_message:
Fix intermittent test case failure due to dict order

The test case expected output relies on the order of strings
generated from the arbitrary ordering of dictionaries.  Change
to be resilient to ordering by using assertIn on each item
instead of assertEqual on the generated list.

Change-Id: Ib4f0586a24846660aedc20517f58fa7ff0dd6cc6
Closes-Bug: 1436424

commit_message:
Initial Erasure Code Docs

This is just the start of some EC docs, the idea is not to add
more content to this patch but instead just to edit/agree on
what's here so far and get it merged to the feature branch so
we've got some living docs going that are reviewable in smaller
patches (as opposed to how we did Storage Policies).

Change-Id: I0403016a4bb7dad9535891632753b0e5e9d402eb
Implements: blueprint swift-ec

Correcting the name of directory holding dev docs

In developing.rst there is an incorrect reference to the
directory in which the docs are generated.

Closes-Bug: #1438983

commit_message:
Introducing ttl to openstack-telemetry

ttl is the time_to_live value that will be configured against database. This value
indicates the expiry time for ceilometer samples

Implements: bluerprint ceilometer-db-cleanup-configuration

(2 comments)

@Brant, Boris, Thought it again, my understanding is we cannot simply remove the content of extension easily, at least in current stage, the code base and the migration scripts is still maintained in a separated directory, and these scripts still useful for something like migration recovering or DB rollback purpose.

One day, these code and dir is combined with the core components as we defined previously and some change in "nova-manage" has been done, then we can safely remove these content and combine them together.

Provide some content for core component's migration since there is need in the real env where we want roll back to an earlier version and recover to the latest version, although those functionality is provided but there is no docs mentioned for that purpose.'}, {'account_id': 13063, 'date': '2015-03-24 06:32:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
More content in the guide for core components' migration

Add some content in `developing.rst` for how to migrate core
components, primarly includes:

- The dir of core components should also includes version
  subdirectory.
- Files: `__init__.py` and `migrate.cfg` also needed for core
  components, so we should start a new section.
- Provide example for core components to upgrade or downgrade.

Change-Id: I7080609c043f856fc923a16473b4a49d5f7d06cd

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-26 14:01:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix for migration 062

MySQL create index for foreign key columns automatically on InnoDB, so
we should remove this index as well after we drop FK.

Related-Bug: #1292591
Change-Id: Ie8c69cc10ebdd805fc5cef82cb08c7d73c70b6e1

commit_message:
Fix for migration 062 on MySQL

MySQL creates indexes for foreign key columns automatically on InnoDB, so
we should remove this index as well now that we have dropped the FK.

Related-Bug: #1292591
Change-Id: Ie8c69cc10ebdd805fc5cef82cb08c7d73c70b6e1

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary .driver. references in assignment manager

There were a number of places in the assignment manager where it
unecessarily used self.driver.<method>(). We only need to use the
.driver. narrowing if there is a method of the same name in the
manager.

Closes bug: 1438529

Change-Id: I462ce94883093571fa0fe21791839f8c8d149c65

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-17 13:30:09.000000000', 'message': 'Make Image Description an input field instead of a textarea

The glanceclient passes the value of the "Description" field as
HTTP headers to the API, completely unmodified.  If there are
newlines in the content, it corrupts the headers and creates havoc.

Encoding/decoding the results is not viable, since arbitrary (and
not necessarily controlled by anyone) clients can retrieve the data.  So as
a dodge, use a normal <input> field for Description instead of
<textarea> field, as newlines are not permitted in the former.

Closes-Bug: 1370732
Change-Id: I0231eaa693e7f36699fda6e011db8c976b639411
(cherry picked from commit 363ccf7b39bb14624e60ee1aa1f08f4e3f5f0642)
'}]
commit_message:
Make Image Description an input field instead of a textarea

The glanceclient passes the value of the "Description" field as
HTTP headers to the API, completely unmodified.  If there are
newlines in the content, it corrupts the headers and creates havoc.

Encoding/decoding the results is not viable, since arbitrary (and
not necessarily controlled by anyone) clients can retrieve the data.  So as
a dodge, use a normal <input> field for Description instead of
<textarea> field, as newlines are not permitted in the former.

Closes-Bug: 1370732
Change-Id: I0231eaa693e7f36699fda6e011db8c976b639411
(cherry picked from commit 363ccf7b39bb14624e60ee1aa1f08f4e3f5f0642)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-26 21:03:14.000000000', 'message': "Add debug logging to quota_reserve flow

There are some places in the quota_reserve flow that could use some
debug logging for helping to figure out the problem when we over quota:

1. Log when we detect a desync in _is_quota_refresh_needed and force a
   refresh.
2. There is a comment in quota_reserve after we call
   _refresh_quota_usages saying we assume the sync was OK and
   essentially everything is hunky dory. Log if we actually refreshed
   without a change to usage.
3. Log the details from project/user quotas/usages when we go over
   quota in _calculate_overquota.
4. Log if we update project_usages using values from user_usages in
   quota_reserve.
5. Finally, before we raise the OverQuota exception in quota_reserve,
   the user_usages dict values are UserQuota objects which are sqla
   dict-like objects and don't stringify nicely for the logs, so
   convert those to actual dict values for logging.

Related-Bug: #1353962

Change-Id: Ic6e3d5fdf51c0a13c97509d0888a3bba00fb3193
"}, {'created': '2015-03-26 21:16:11.000000000', 'message': "Add debug logging to quota_reserve flow

There are some places in the quota_reserve flow that could use some
debug logging for helping to figure out the problem when we over quota:

1. Log when we detect a desync in _is_quota_refresh_needed and force a
   refresh.
2. There is a comment in quota_reserve after we call
   _refresh_quota_usages saying we assume the sync was OK and
   essentially everything is hunky dory. Log if we actually refreshed
   without a change to usage.
3. Log the details from project/user quotas/usages when we go over
   quota in _calculate_overquota.
4. Log if we update project_usages using values from user_usages in
   quota_reserve.
5. Finally, before we raise the OverQuota exception in quota_reserve,
   the user_usages dict values are UserQuota objects which are sqla
   dict-like objects and don't stringify nicely for the logs, so
   convert those to actual dict values for logging.

Related-Bug: #1353962

Change-Id: Ic6e3d5fdf51c0a13c97509d0888a3bba00fb3193
"}]
commit_message:
Add debug logging to quota_reserve flow

There are some places in the quota_reserve flow that could use some
debug logging for helping to figure out the problem when we over quota:

1. Log when we detect a desync in _is_quota_refresh_needed and force a
   refresh.
2. There is a comment in quota_reserve after we call
   _refresh_quota_usages saying we assume the sync was OK and
   essentially everything is hunky dory. Log if we actually refreshed
   without a change to usage.
3. Log the details from project/user quotas/usages when we go over
   quota in _calculate_overquota.
4. Log if we update project_usages using values from user_usages in
   quota_reserve.
5. Finally, before we raise the OverQuota exception in quota_reserve,
   the user_usages dict values are UserQuota objects which are sqla
   dict-like objects and don't stringify nicely for the logs, so
   convert those to actual dict values for logging.

Related-Bug: #1353962

Change-Id: Ic6e3d5fdf51c0a13c97509d0888a3bba00fb3193

commit_message:
swift updates for roles and services

* update role to match our chef repo
* allow platform service names
* improved logging
* use memcache list from common
* remove old unneeded templates and service providers
* add ring gzone and region attributes
* cleanup deprecated get_secret calls
* add templates for sync, expirer and recon
* added more tests

Sorry for the long patch, but this cookbook has been difficult
to deal with.

Change-Id: I2373d65b02c56ada1be8703be0492fab3597be26
Implements: blueprint object-storage-cleanup

commit_message:
Don't autodoc the test suite

Don't build API documentation for the keystoneclient tests. These are
not public functions, pollute the existing docs, and extend the time
required to build docs.

Change-Id: I1206a808272d19b342d26f5117aedafb476d0994

commit_message:
Add support to create ECP assertion based on a token

A user should be able to exchange their token for an ECP wrapped
SAML assertion.

implements bp generate-saml-assertions

Change-Id: Ic9c20aebc5cd91650576ad050c09779df54f1d94

commit_message:
Create an event when signalling fails

- otherwise it is hard to know that signalling happened and failed
- remove the LOG.exception() - doesn't seem like a programming error.
- don't change the resource action/state
- this makes a functional test much more reliable

Change-Id: I84c73b06bade4dfcadba240eb3dddac698194acf
Partial-bug: #1334333

commit_message:
Correctly initialize copies of stack during updating stack

Pass stack_user_project_id to updated_stack, backup_stack and
oldstack to make sure the success when deleting stack domain user.

Create a common method to get the kwargs to create a stack from
an existing stack.

Co-Authored-By: Angus Salkeld <asalkeld@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ieb7726ed738d5ae8046184f312379b9132b6c4a9
Closes-Bug: #1356084

commit_message:
Fetch user's projects from request.user

Instead of hitting the backend api, the user's projects
can be fetched from request.user.

Change-Id: I9cbdeded40d4cc4f54ff0c52f5fd8ea7280ef7cf
Closes-Bug: #1439338

commit_message:
Add support to create SAML assertion based on a token

A user should be able to exchange their token for a SAML assertion
that is valid on a service provider (the user should must provide
this data).

implements bp generate-saml-assertions

Change-Id: I5cb635929c7f6823ab1e4b1db5e48045be9e0737

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-30 01:31:10.000000000', 'message': "Ignore unexpected kwargs to auth plugins

When creating an auth plugin, extra arguments might get passed in
by the application that the auth plugin doesn't care about. This
was causing a TypeError due to unexpected keyword arguments. These
extra arguments should just be ignored instead.

Change-Id: Iaef9cc0a2cca7cf7b7a1d17de49db9bef40127bf
Closes-Bug: 1437976
"}]
commit_message:
Ignore unexpected kwargs to auth plugins

When creating an auth plugin, extra arguments might get passed in
by the application that the auth plugin doesn't care about. This
was causing a TypeError due to unexpected keyword arguments. These
extra arguments should just be ignored instead.

Change-Id: Iaef9cc0a2cca7cf7b7a1d17de49db9bef40127bf
Closes-Bug: 1437976

    getctime(filename)
        Return the metadata change time of a file, reported by os.stat().
    
    getmtime(filename)
        Return the last modification time of a file, reported by os.stat().


In [11]: print  os.path.getmtime('./1')
1427851560.72

In [12]: print  os.path.getctime('./1')
1427851560.72

In [13]: help (os.path)

[{'created': '2015-03-31 22:18:34.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid reloading policy files in policy.d for every call

We added policy files in policy.d, currently, the code will reload the policy
in policy.d every enforce been called.

This patch changes read_cached_file to store the cache information of the
directory. And we check if the policy.d fresh or not before work though it.

Co-Authored-By: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com>
Change-Id: Ia8c273c8566a4b472cb8807b1576ef1dee8ef054
