commit_message:
Avoid reloading policy files in policy.d for every call

We added policy files in policy.d, currently, the code will
reload the policy in policy.d every enforce been called.

This patch caches the file mtime of the most newest file in
the directory (or the directory itself if it is empty) and uses
that to detect if we need to reload files in the policy.d
directory.

Closes-Bug: 1437992
Co-Authored-By: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com>
Change-Id: Ia8c273c8566a4b472cb8807b1576ef1dee8ef054

subject: Deal with CentOS 7.1 breakage
messages:
[{'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2015-04-01 22:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-01 22:55:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-kolla-bashate http://logs.openstack.org/41/169941/1/check/gate-kolla-bashate/6b46329/ : FAILURE in 6s (non-voting)

- check-kolla-functional-f21 http://logs.openstack.org/41/169941/1/check/check-kolla-functional-f21/5a3e4b1/ : SUCCESS in 3s'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2015-04-01 23:00:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6836, 'date': '2015-04-01 23:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-01 23:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-kolla-bashate http://logs.openstack.org/41/169941/2/check/gate-kolla-bashate/5ce6326/ : FAILURE in 7s (non-voting)
- gate-kolla-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/41/169941/2/check/gate-kolla-pep8/4179221/ : SUCCESS in 29s
- check-kolla-functional-f21 http://logs.openstack.org/41/169941/2/check/check-kolla-functional-f21/f007a1e/ : SUCCESS in 8s'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2015-04-02 01:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

So, I looked a little bit at this issue and it seems https://rdo.fedorapeople.org/rdo-release.rpm is busted.

In the source package, I see:

RELEASEVER='$releasever'
if ! grep -qFi 'fedora' /etc/redhat-release; then
  DIST=epel # Should this be something else (maybe el)?
  FDIST=el
  # $releasever doesn't seem to be a reliable way to get the major version on RHEL
  # e.g. if distroverpkg isn't present in yum.conf mine was set to 6Server
  # because this was the version of the package redhat-release-server-6Server
  RELEASEVER=$(sed -e 's/.*release \([0-9]\+\).*/\1/' /etc/redhat-release)
fi

meaning that $RELEASEVER contains the value of /etc/redhat-release instead of value of $releasever for systems other than Fedora. And in case of CentOS 7.1, /etc/redhat-release contains "Derived from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.1 (Source)".

We'd better fix upstream package, but in the meantime I'm OK with the workaround.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-02 01:06:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Verified

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-02 01:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+2

Build succeeded (gate pipeline).

- gate-kolla-functional-f21 http://logs.openstack.org/41/169941/2/gate/gate-kolla-functional-f21/b629f0f/ : SUCCESS in 7s'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-02 01:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

Fix space issues in log and exception messages

Fixed space issues in log and exception messages as per standards
followed by the oslo.config project.
Please refer to this URL for more details:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.config/styleguide.html#format

The standard is, for multi-line strings, add the space at the end of
a line and not at the beginning of new line whereas for single-line
string, do not add space at the end of the line.

Closes-Bug: #1373266
Change-Id: Ic96d3a179669e02504d8e51197ef1c32cc34d793
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed space issues

Fix space issues in log and exception messages

Fixed space issues in log and exception messages as per standards
followed by the oslo.config project.
Please refer to this URL for more details:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.config/styleguide.html#format

The standard is, for multi-line strings, add the space at the end of
a line and not at the beginning of new line whereas for single-line
string, do not add space at the end of the line.

Closes-Bug: #1373266
Change-Id: Ic96d3a179669e02504d8e51197ef1c32cc34d793

commit_message:
Stop stacktracing in _get_filter_uuid

I5cd28308da9141fa8b2884b27209b5962543b0fd mistakenly caused a stacktrace
instead of just logging the libvirt error message.

Conflicts:
        nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_firewall.py
        nova/virt/libvirt/firewall.py

Related-Bug: 1419905
Closes-Bug: 1430383
Co-Authored-By: Matt Riedemann <mriedem@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Ifa28262aae87f9ddba48b0161b1e401a5d7d9c00
(cherry picked from commit 7446d4065343fafa1f5e3452f78ae21b2f67ae3c)

[{'created': '2015-03-24 18:34:43.000000000', 'message': 'Set force_config_drive=False for Juno Ironic

Config drive was not supported by Ironic in Juno and this parameter was
effectively ignored.  It is now supported in Kilo but keeping this enabled
in Juno prevents partial upgrades (Kilo Nova with Juno Ironic).  This
disables it on the Juno side to facilitate partial upgrade testing with

commit_message:
Set force_config_drive=False for Juno Ironic

Config drive was not supported by Ironic in Juno and this parameter was
effectively ignored.  It is now supported in Kilo but keeping this enabled
in Juno prevents partial upgrades (Kilo Nova with Juno Ironic).  This
disables it on the Juno side to facilitate partial upgrade testing with
Grenade.

Change-Id: Id473ea81bd945959cd75575bb85a05a1dfe25ae7
Related-bug: #1433727

Change-Id is Ok, cherry-pick is Ok, commit already merged on master.

There is a small difference between the commits (show_deleted=False). I see that the difference is due to another bug fix that did not get into juno (a little bit too late): https://review.openstack.org/#/c/122608/

At a first glance, the linked commit can be backported to Juno (proposed in sep 19). So, if that will be backported before this, the test added in this commit will be a little bit... wrong.

So, I suggest backporting the commit I've mentioned and put this commit on top of it, so the conflicts will be kept to a minimum. :)

Cheers!

Claudiu"}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2015-04-01 17:53:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-01 17:53:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Verified

commit_message:
Move orphaned api test

A recent change added a new api test to the old location that is no
longer used for discovery.  This change moves it to
neutron/tests/api/admin to ensure that it can be discovered and run.

Change-Id: Ifcada8f9b2178b3159151b0d1953fd841d82ffa6

commit_message:
Set IP_VERSION in DevStack to run dual stack

This change sets IP_VERSION to "4+6" which will configure DevStack to
run dual-stacked. Currently, only Neutron honors this flag, by creating
IPv6 ULA networks and adding them to routers that are created during the
initial network setup[1].

[1]: I848abf18e00e2a869697c5ef6366bc567dde448a

Change-Id: I3d416275f77913769b98e77f7e47bed17fc4d1cc
Depends-On: I150da5938e79eeef0c947ddb1a4282e37d0515ee

commit_message:
A mixin for jsonpatch requests validation

A JSONPatch-enabled API requires validation logic which will check the
correctness of incoming request body according to schema. A mixin is
added which will do such validations.

Such validation logic may be useful not only for Artifacts API but also
for regular v2 images API, as it also uses JSONPatch notation in its
update calls. So this mixin may be used in future in Images API as well.

Implements-blueprint: artifact-repository
Change-Id: I1b7b72bcc0a0455803a4e99dd17a9732b0dd7a8d

subject: Add link to the TC documentation
messages:
[{'account_id': 4656, 'date': '2015-03-31 00:26:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-31 00:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-openstack-manuals-tox-checkniceness http://logs.openstack.org/22/169122/1/check/gate-openstack-manuals-tox-checkniceness/70cb99a/ : SUCCESS in 2m 13s
- gate-openstack-manuals-tox-checkdeletions http://logs.openstack.org/22/169122/1/check/gate-openstack-manuals-tox-checkdeletions/771432f/ : SUCCESS in 2m 12s
- gate-openstack-manuals-tox-doc-publish-checkbuild http://docs-draft.openstack.org/22/169122/1/check/gate-openstack-manuals-tox-doc-publish-checkbuild/294837c//publish-docs/ : SUCCESS in 3m 08s'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2015-03-31 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This is the wrong place IMHO. I suggest you bring it up at the TC meeting or on the mailing list and look for a better place.

What about enhancing "Your representatives" with the TC on
http://www.openstack.org/community/ ?'}, {'account_id': 4656, 'date': '2015-03-31 08:25:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm a little frustrated by the suggestion that I haven't put this in the right place. The title of the site is "OpenStack Technical Committee Governance Documents" - that means to me that a link from docs.openstack.org makes sense.

There are currently no links to governance.openstack.org at all.

https://www.google.com.tw/search?q=link:governance.openstack.org&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&gws_rd=cr&ei=2FkaVcTKE6G7mQWPo4HoCg'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2015-03-31 08:41:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sean, I agree that there should be a link to it.


I disagree that http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/ is the best place for this link.

Let's wait for Anne on her suggestions.

A bug report against the openstack web pages might be a good next step."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2015-03-31 14:20:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sean, it's a mismatch in audience. The audience for governance is going to Google to search first, so definitely we need to address the issue. But it needs to either go on docs.openstack.org/developer/ or www."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2015-03-31 14:20:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Woops meant to -1.'}, {'account_id': 4656, 'date': '2015-04-02 00:08:54.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add link to the TC documentation

It was difficult to find governance.openstack.org, after looking for the
results of Ib6e2a0f2c6ebd620148620a48abd2447bb360479 merging - it did
not show up on the list of results in Google when searching for
"OpenStack governance"

Change-Id: I78ead21243b7d7bb1c632acaa138a6ac626eb3cb

Expanding on my comments above, I am copying and pasting this from my comments in another patch.

I'd like to be able to see something like the following on step configuration variables:

requiredServices : ['network']

This would automatically use the serviceCatalog.ifTypeEnabled('network') to validate that that service is enabled before loading / displaying the step. There are two others that will come up in the future (NOT TO BE CONSIDERED AT THE MOMENT:

requiredPolicies : [] // Will automatically check the policy service. 

requiredConfigSetting: [] // Will check config settings to see if the step is enabled. So something like the following where it can be enabled / disabled and where perhaps defaults or other settings can be passed through.

wizardname{ step1: {enabled: false}}"}, {'account_id': 7665, 'date': '2015-03-21 06:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Just thinking that the legacy horizon code has a "permissions" attribute on anything that they need to determine whether or not to show.

permissions = ('openstack.roles.admin', 'openstack.services.volume',)

We could add the same to each step.  And we could expose the permissions code on horizon now as a REST API endpoint.  Then the same format could be used.

I'll look into that and we should talk with David about it.'}, {'account_id': 13805, 'date': '2015-03-22 03:28:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Patch Set 14 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-22 04:08:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Verified+1

commit_message:
Launch Instance - MultiRegion Support / Networks

This makes it so that networks are only provided
if the network service is enabled.

This bugfix also adds multi-region support.

Details on how to setup a multi-region test
to verify it in horizon are in the bug.

Closes-Bug: #1432401
Co-Authored-By: Shaoquan Chen <sean.chen2@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Brian Tully <brian.tully@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Richard Jones <r1chardj0n3s@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I4e98c18b579eb5fc9e1b76ddf57d22142a7ddeab

(5 comments)

No scoring because I believe it's still in WIP - since it lacks unit tests.

Please have a look at the comments inside. Most of them are nits or questions, but I've realized we're trying again to set config values dependent on db settings. I will find links for previous references, but in the meanwhile I'm proposing two alternatives. I know that it might be already too late to even think about an alternative, but please have a look at them anyway.

Also, I have a portability question regarding default subnet pools:
Assume I write an app that uses openstack API creating a subnet assuming that there is a default pool. 
I use that app with a deployment that has the default pool - and everything works fine; then I move to another deployment without the default pool and it fails. The failure is easily understandable, but programmatically working around it is very difficult as  the user has no way afaict to tell whether a subnet has a default pool or not - and as an app developer I would have to parse the error message and then submit the request with a cidr.
That does not seem great from a usability perspective, does it?"}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2015-03-30 17:06:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-26 18:11:40.000000000', 'message': 'Honor the default ipv6 pool configuration setting

Change-Id: I301189b5cd31d7c5fa4a40fa3e04f8e6ac77592b
Partially-Implements: blueprint subnet-allocation
'}, {'created': '2015-03-27 17:24:24.000000000', 'message': 'Honor the default ipv6 pool configuration setting

Change-Id: I301189b5cd31d7c5fa4a40fa3e04f8e6ac77592b
Partially-Implements: blueprint subnet-allocation
'}, {'created': '2015-03-27 18:33:56.000000000', 'message': 'Implement default subnet pool configuration settings

The default_ipv6_subnet_pool option was added [1] as an integration
point between prefix delegation work and subnet allocation work.  This
patch completes the integration with subnet allocation.  This
addresses the use case where a deployer wants all ipv6 addresses to
come -- by default -- from a globally routable pool of ipv6 addresses.

In a deployment with this option set, an API user can still access the
old behavior by passing None explicitly as subnetpool_id when creating
a subnet.

This patch also adds the default_ipv4_subnet_pool for completeness.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/166973

Change-Id: I301189b5cd31d7c5fa4a40fa3e04f8e6ac77592b
Partially-Implements: blueprint subnet-allocation
'}, {'created': '2015-03-27 21:08:50.000000000', 'message': 'Implement default subnet pool configuration settings

The default_ipv6_subnet_pool option was added [1] as an integration
point between prefix delegation work and subnet allocation work.  This
patch completes the integration with subnet allocation.  This
addresses the use case where a deployer wants all ipv6 addresses to
come -- by default -- from a globally routable pool of ipv6 addresses.

In a deployment with this option set, an API user can still access the
old behavior by passing None explicitly as subnetpool_id when creating
a subnet.

This patch also adds the default_ipv4_subnet_pool for completeness.

commit_message:
Implement default subnet pool configuration settings

The default_ipv6_subnet_pool option was added [1] as an integration
point between prefix delegation work and subnet allocation work.  This
patch completes the integration with subnet allocation.  This
addresses the use case where a deployer wants all ipv6 addresses to
come -- by default -- from a globally routable pool of ipv6 addresses.

In a deployment with this option set, an API user can still access the
old behavior by passing None explicitly as subnetpool_id when creating
a subnet.

This patch also adds the default_ipv4_subnet_pool for completeness.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/166973

Change-Id: I301189b5cd31d7c5fa4a40fa3e04f8e6ac77592b
Partially-Implements: blueprint subnet-allocation

A recent devstack change broke the ironic agent_ssh tempest job. The
author had no way of knowing this was broken because the agent_ssh job
does not run against devstack.

The requirements and cross-project interactions are very different for
pxe_ssh vs agent_ssh, so both jobs should continue to run.

Change-Id: Ic8ae9dd70f5a19d953700280e37e97a3bbd461c3
'}]
commit_message:
Make devstack check ironic agent_ssh tempest job

A recent devstack change broke the ironic agent_ssh tempest job. The
author had no way of knowing this was broken because the agent_ssh job
does not run against devstack.

The requirements and cross-project interactions are very different for
pxe_ssh vs agent_ssh, so both jobs should continue to run.

Change-Id: Ic8ae9dd70f5a19d953700280e37e97a3bbd461c3

commit_message:
Denote that 2.6 testing is still happening

Since we run 2.6 CI tests (and the setup.cfg
classifiers so we support 2.6); we might as well mention
this in the docs.

Change-Id: I9b59378f717f7df280c429a53d0a83c129327481

commit_message:
passing wrong dict in lbaas

While updating the member and health monitor in lbass,
the resultant dict passing to the constructor is not uniform with the other methods(get and create).

This will cause a KeyError, if we access the dict values.

This patch making the dict uniform with all the methods.

Change-Id: I8b58a0acb4153358b9ed4a46794aaccce181e31b
Closes-Bug: #1438533

commit_message:
Add --location option to image create

Allow images to be created using glance's --location option
instead of always requiring --copy-from

Change-Id: I2aae47570f09a695adb032c210d7dc770f8cb746
Closes-Bug: #1433819

subject: This is a reference for code review
messages:
[{'account_id': 10477, 'date': '2014-11-20 23:51:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-21 00:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-octavia-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/84/136184/1/check/gate-octavia-pep8/6b73eee : SUCCESS in 1m 09s
- gate-octavia-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/84/136184/1/check/gate-octavia-python26/b515b7f : SUCCESS in 1m 28s
- gate-octavia-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/84/136184/1/check/gate-octavia-python27/305292f : SUCCESS in 1m 14s'}, {'account_id': 11685, 'date': '2014-11-25 00:38:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Min: It looks like most of this was pulled verbatim from the code standards here:  http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/

I started to comment to this effect, but I think it would actually be not very useful for us to just repeat this documentation in the code for this project. Also the HACKING.rst already makes reference to the main OpenStack hacking document, and points out the couple of Octavia-specific things we're doing with this project.

I think this document should be more of a how-to or etiquette guide for people reviewing code in gerrit on this project. This should cover things like:

* When is appropriate to "-1"
* When is it appropriate to "+1"
* What about features you would like to see added to a given spec?
* What about 'short-term-code' or placeholder code which is meant to be replaced at a later date?
* How large of a window should a core review allow after the first +2 before the code is merged?
* What is you see a serious problem with code that was merged?

...and other topics like this. The specific standards are covered elsewhere (and we should make reference to them, but not just repeat them here). This document should be about how to be an effective reviewer.'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2014-11-30 00:52:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Is this typical for openstack projects?  If so, I'll remove my -2."}, {'account_id': 10477, 'date': '2014-12-02 00:17:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11685, 'date': '2014-12-02 04:52:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Doug-- I have no idea whether it's normal for there to be code review guidelines within projects. You may be right though-- this is probably something more appropriate for a generalized wiki article (or update of something existing) on the OpenStack wiki, since what I'm thinking we're after here isn't unique to Octavia, and there are probably standards people are following with regard to code review that span projects."}, {'account_id': 11685, 'date': '2014-12-02 04:59:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10477, 'date': '2014-12-03 20:19:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11685, 'date': '2014-12-05 04:10:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10477, 'date': '2015-04-01 23:31:34.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

no need it anymore'}]

Change-Id: I084f007bb8eb7f081d5ae56aa919f15f9596984b
"}]
commit_message:
This is a reference for code review

It wraps up some commonly used standard for python code and gerrit
code review requirements, this document is expected to help those
who submit their code and review others' code.

Timur, I think you should mention the unit of the setting in comments and in the doc: "[...] size *in bytes* [...]".

Less important but a setting in KB would be more readable.
For instance to set 1 MB, it's easier and more readable than 1048576:

FILE_TRANSFER_CHUNK_SIZE_KB = 1024'}, {'account_id': 8040, 'date': '2015-03-19 18:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8040, 'date': '2015-03-19 18:17:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 8040, 'date': '2015-03-19 18:22:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@Romain, I've fixed the docs. Still I am inclined to keep this setting specified in plain bytes because specifying it in KB (more readable, no argue!) could introduce some misunderstanding when the developer thinks the value is still in Kilobytes while it was already translated to bytes. Just forgetting where the KB->B translation takes place will surely cause such situations."}, {'account_id': 8876, 'date': '2015-03-19 18:29:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

To prevent memory overrun when downloading large objects from Swift
* resp_chunk_size keyword to swiftclient should be used
* obj.data iterator returned by swiftclient is passed to HttpResponse
  as usual since it works both with iterators and memory buffers.

In case the code is run against Django<1.5 the standard HttpResponse
is used, otherwise we built upon StreamingHttpResponse introduced in
Django 1.5 since it's was designed specifically for the purpose of
large files transfer.

Change-Id: I18e5809b86bfa24948dc642da2a55dffaa1a4ce1
Closes-Bug: #1427819
"}, {'created': '2015-03-13 16:22:42.000000000', 'message': "Fix web-server memory overrun when downloading objects from Swift

  (or StreamingHttpResponse for Django>=1.5) as usual since both response
  classes work with iterators/files/byte strings (yet StreamingHttpResponse

commit_message:
Fix web-server memory overrun when downloading objects from Swift

To prevent memory overrun when downloading large objects from Swift
* `resp_chunk_size` keyword should be passed to swiftclient
* `obj.data` iterator returned from swiftclient is passed to HttpResponse
  (or StreamingHttpResponse for Django>=1.5) as usual since both response
  classes work with iterators/files/byte strings (yet StreamingHttpResponse
  does it better).

The commit introduces new setting SWIFT_FILE_TRANSFER_CHUNK_SIZE that
defines the size of chunk in bytes for Swift objects downloading.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I18e5809b86bfa24948dc642da2a55dffaa1a4ce1
Closes-Bug: #1427819

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-30 20:57:25.000000000', 'message': 'Reorder tox environments

If py34 is run after py2x, it results in a "db type could not be
determined" error.  The only current way to avoid that is to run
py34 first.

Change-Id: Id81e127e71ecd04a2ed16ab899d6fbf0d15bfee3
'}]
commit_message:
Reorder tox environments

If py34 is run after py2x, it results in a "db type could not be
determined" error.  The only current way to avoid that is to run
py34 first.

The only problem I see is that the page is saved even if the test is successful, so either the commit message is changed or the code is adapted to store the image only when the test fails. What about using TestCase.addOnException to call a function which saves the content and invokes addDetails?'}, {'account_id': 12355, 'date': '2015-03-05 11:30:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8577, 'date': '2015-03-05 11:32:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

LGTM. Tom what do you think about Luigi's point?"}, {'account_id': 12954, 'date': '2015-03-05 11:51:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Luigi has an excellent point, patch should be modified to use the addOnException method.

But there is one more thing that strikes me as bad and that is the format of the output. I would prefer to have this html output saved in the separate log file. What do you think? Any idea how to achieve this behavior?'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2015-03-05 12:11:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Maybe it's just a matter of adding the detail with the right MIME type, something like (WARNING, untested code):

self.addDetail('failed-page.html', Content(ContentType('text', 'html'), lambda: html_file_as_list))"}, {'account_id': 12954, 'date': '2015-03-05 12:57:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 12954, 'date': '2015-03-05 13:05:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I have implemented it using the addOnException method, but as i was testing the code on the test_login method i realized that previous scenario would not work for every test case (because login tests were derived from BasetestCase as such there was no self.home_pg property which i could use in the teardown) therefore i moved the get_page_source method from pageobject file to BasetestCase class.

I did not figure out yet how to make the gate display the .html file in the separate log file. Any suggestions are more than welcome.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-05 14:07:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-02-23 21:50:36.000000000', 'message': "Add html source code on test failure for debugging

Sometimes it is not possible to reproduce failure in integration test
locally. Adding html source code of page where failure happened should
increase our ability to debug properly errors on the gates.For this
purpose is used addDetail method from testtools package.

Following changes were done:

* TestCase and AdminTestCase classes were modified in order to share
  common functionality and remove code repetition.

* Testcases have been modified in order to use newly introduce class
  variables(TEST_USER_NAME, TEST_PASSWORD, CONFIG).

* Method get_page_source has been created in the BasePage class this
  method uses javascript innerHTML attribute in order to make
  javascript modification to the page visible in the output. (javascript
  modificaton would not been visible if webdriver's property page_source
  has beend used)

Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing

Change-Id: I064405337fb68c966da007f2a5bf91d5c0ec2b3d

commit_message:
Add html source code on test failure for debugging

Sometimes it is not possible to reproduce failure in integration test
locally. Adding html source code of page where failure happened should
increase our ability to debug properly errors on the gates. For this
purpose the addDetail method from testtools package is used.

Following changes were done:

* TestCase and AdminTestCase classes were modified in order to share
  common functionality and remove code repetition.

* Testcases have been modified in order to use newly introduce class
  variables(TEST_USER_NAME, TEST_PASSWORD, CONFIG).

* Methods _get_page_html_source and _dump_page_html_source have been created
  in the BaseTestCase class. _get_page_html_source uses javascript innerHTML
  attribute in order to make javascript modification to the page visible
  in the output. (javascript modificaton would not have been visible if
  webdriver's property page_source was used)

Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing

Change-Id: I064405337fb68c966da007f2a5bf91d5c0ec2b3d

commit_message:
Docs on HardwareManager, building, and workflow

Documentation on IPA hardware managers, how to build an IPA ramdisk
and some ways Ironic interacts with the IPA API.

Change-Id: I94db188e1e1333e71437f551d1dfe00acdd7fc8a
Co-Authored-By: Josh Gachnang <josh@servercobra.com>

[{'created': '2015-03-06 22:37:38.000000000', 'message': "Add a feature variable for port mac address update

Neutron allows the 'mac_address' of a port to be updated starting in
kilo-2.  In order to add tempest tests for this minor feature, we need

commit_message:
Add a feature variable for port mac address update

Neutron allows the 'mac_address' of a port to be updated starting in
kilo-2.  In order to add tempest tests for this minor feature, we need
a switch so the test can skip on earlier releases.

Change-Id: I82fdfc14fa96ae288c1874e227e34356cd86befd
Partial-bug: #1426002

commit_message:
Removing unused code in API

This code was left over as part of adding RabbitMQ username and
password support configuration and is not used.

Change-Id: If6317f51479d45e834d6ae663fb01e87f4ea280b
closes-bug: 1438857

commit_message:
Added additional core related cpu and aggregated disk metrics

Added 1 additional cpu core metrics and 2 rollup disk metrics.
Added a configuration parameter to the disk plugin configuration
to enable/disable the aggregated disk metrics. Also added additional
documentation to the README file to reflect how to add dimensions
to a plugin instance.

Change-Id: I7e73f7103afa1e3e366769d56eb91233f5513726

commit_message:
Define bridge/port fixtures for OVS/LinuxBridge/Veth backends

This change defines for OVS, LinuxBridge and veth[1] bridge and port
fixture classes in order to handle bridge and port setUp/cleanUp.

It allows to simplify BaseOVSLinuxTestCase[2] and remove
BaseBridgeTestCase[2].

[1] veth backend simulates a bridge with a veth
[2] in neutron.tests.functional.agent.linux.base

Change-Id: If34c9a8fb6fa584fb1e30173ec619d1aac9701f9

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-01 20:37:53.000000000', 'message': "Remove setting language to en_US for 'venv'

Remove setting LANGUAGE=en_US for 'venv' virtualenv.

Since the 'venv' environment is not used for unittests and users may
want to see messages in their native language in the 'venv' virtualenv.

Also makes it consistent with python-ironicclient

Change-Id: I1902d162cc7a5a1c8ee2e6a7412096d645277cc0
"}]
commit_message:
Remove setting language to en_US for 'venv'

Remove setting LANGUAGE=en_US for 'venv' virtualenv.

Since the 'venv' environment is not used for unittests and users may
want to see messages in their native language in the 'venv' virtualenv.

Also makes it consistent with python-ironicclient

Change-Id: I1902d162cc7a5a1c8ee2e6a7412096d645277cc0

commit_message:
Nova metadata protocol should be configurable

Metadata agent request nova metadata endpoint by default via http,
it will get issue if nova's endpoints are over https. The configuration
should be part of puppet.

Change-Id: Id57b81a8f8f0998f363ee9ee8f0a162d279dcaf9
Closes-bug: #1439034

Two unit tests were reporting as taking over 5 seconds each.  Updated
them to mock time.sleep() and they no longer show up in the longest
tests list.

The unit tests were:
  * test_wsman_enumerate_retry()
  * test_wsman_invoke_retry()

Change-Id: I7c2a0539d239313f8706a0e8f24b3ff88cccf29f

commit_message:
Mock time.sleep() for two unittests

Two unit tests were reporting as taking over 5 seconds each.  Updated
them to mock time.sleep() and they no longer show up in the longest
tests list.

The unit tests were:
  * test_wsman_enumerate_retry()
  * test_wsman_invoke_retry()

Change-Id: I7c2a0539d239313f8706a0e8f24b3ff88cccf29f

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-01 19:14:57.000000000', 'message': 'Fix intermittent unit test failures

The following tests have been failing recently:

 test_update_add_locations_status_exception
 test_update_replace_duplicate_locations
 test_update_replace_locations_status_exception

They were querying storeurl.com which redirected to
www.hugedomains.com, and unexpected exchanges, eg:

 HTTP/1.1 302 Found.
 Cache-Control: private.
 Content-Length: 183.
 Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8.
 Date: Wed, 01 Apr 2015 19:05:15 GMT.
 Location: http://www.hugedomains.com/domain_profile.cfm?d=storeurl&e=com.
 Server: Microsoft-IIS/8.0.
 X-Powered-By: ASP.NET.
 Connection: keep-alive.

Mocking out the get_size function prevents these real connections.

Change-Id: Ia5d867f98ac60479c70362b0477c2a0571ac6e4f
Closes-bug: 1437346
'}]
commit_message:
Fix intermittent unit test failures

The following tests have been failing recently:

 test_update_add_locations_status_exception
 test_update_replace_duplicate_locations
 test_update_replace_locations_status_exception

They were querying storeurl.com which redirected to
www.hugedomains.com, and unexpected exchanges, eg:

 HTTP/1.1 302 Found.
 Cache-Control: private.
 Content-Length: 183.
 Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8.
 Date: Wed, 01 Apr 2015 19:05:15 GMT.
 Location: http://www.hugedomains.com/domain_profile.cfm?d=storeurl&e=com.
 Server: Microsoft-IIS/8.0.
 X-Powered-By: ASP.NET.
 Connection: keep-alive.

Mocking out the get_size function prevents these real connections.

Change-Id: Ia5d867f98ac60479c70362b0477c2a0571ac6e4f
Closes-bug: 1437346

commit_message:
Change where we look for ROOT_PATH

ROOT_PATH should be the parent of the directory containing local_settings.py,
setting it wrong has started causing problems as its now used as part of
CUSTOM_THEME_PATH.

Change-Id: I6306ec21813b672d44830f3bac81a5ea5fbde0dc
Closes-Bug: #1438133

commit_message:
Combine test cases for checking nova limits response

nova rate-limit returns absolute limits too, but novaclient does
not show absolute limit,a bug
(https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-novaclient/+bug/1172254) has
been filed for this one. There is no test which assert on both
absolute and rate limit. This patch assert on both the rate and
absolute limit returned

Change-Id: Ia635f32eefc46e22e3f4e45a7885f492bb967a99
Closes-Bug: #1436653

commit_message:
Add help text to DeleteVolumeTransfer action

The DeleteVolumeTransfer action doesn't inherit from BatchAction
therefore does not get a default help_text attribute, this patch adds
help_text for the action so its consistant with the other delete
actions.
It also makes sure the confirmation dialog doesn't display undefined
help_text in the future.

Change-Id: Ib5bdd55931206d22095dc2872e45be017a57bdd1
Closes-Bug: 1437529

commit_message:
[Launch Instance Fix] Cleanup $scope injection in help controllers

This patch removes $scope dependency injection in Launch Instance
help controllers that no longer use $scope.

Also added one-time binding in help templates.

Change-Id: I5ca40f0d573ec3816b6a61c7d2aaf2fdad1db800
Closes-Bug: #1436456

commit_message:
Handle RequestURITooLong error in large instance table

Neutron API supports filtering in listing API. If long filter parameters
such as long UUID list are passed, it exceeds URL length limit and
RequestURITooLong is raised. In such case, we need to split filter
parameters into chunks.

This commit add a convenient method to handle the case, which split
a list of long filter parameter into chunks and repeat listing API call.
However, it is not easy to generalize this behavior because filtering
parameters are specific to caller's logic, so this patch only fixes
a problem in servers_update_addresses().

Closes-Bug: #1349841
(cherry picked from commit 6e1da2634412afdb21fd5a3f27c1da1d332680f7)
(cherry picked from commit d4bc8a0dc1ab8afb25fad4c04fb4132812c8af04)

Conflicts:
	openstack_dashboard/api/neutron.py
	openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/network_tests.py
	openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/neutron_tests.py

Change-Id: I63ec4bad722351f640797bcbec4a38d5972f135c

This patch is trying to fix the case of calling the detach API, which is called by tempest without begin_detaching. The latter API call is the one that does the state checks and ensures that the volume has attachments, and must be called before detach. This is production code for the sake of having a poorly-written test pass, which is wrong IMO - better to have the test make the proper API calls.

Further, calling the detach API without begin_detaching allows for concurrent detaches, which will break code (including the code here which is racy if called from multiple instances).

In short, I suggest to fix the test.'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2015-03-24 16:08:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Incorrect.  This test is trying to cover the case where people incorrectly call detach again after all attachments have been detached.   people/code do dumb things all the time.  Yes, the tempest tests shouldn't call detach twice.  But Cinder shouldn't puke with an invalid index error either.

This patch is only trying to be safe with reading attachments out of the list and raising a meaningful message  of "no attachments" instead of invalid index.

It's entirely out of the scope of this patch to fix the communication between tempest/nova and cinder.'}, {'account_id': 13203, 'date': '2015-03-24 16:10:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck huawei-volume-ci'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2015-03-24 16:22:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Be safe with getting attachment

The volume manager wasn't being safe with trying to pull an
attachment out of the attachments list.  It's possible someone
is calling the manager to detach a volume that has no attachments.

This patch raises an InvalidVolume exception if we detect that
there are no attachments left to detach.

Change-Id: I684ed870d13a4efc6f64b0144c987e355428bc54
Closes-Bug: #1435574

- gate-python-heatclient-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/19/149319/3/check/gate-python-heatclient-python27/c5258ea/ : SUCCESS in 46s'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2015-01-27 22:24:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Pulled and tested, the setting of breakpoints works well, but I don't think we ideally want to force folks to look up the nested stack ID to unset nested breakpoints.

E.g, if I do this:

heat stack-create tl4 -f two_level_nested.yaml -e env.yaml --breakpoint foo/server2

where "foo" is a provider resource which creates a nested stack containing a resource called "server2", the breakpoint is set as expected in the nested stack.

To clear the breakpoint, I expected to be able to do:

heat clear-breakpoints tl4 foo/server2

But this doesn't work atm.

Also, is there any way we can validate the resource passed to clear-breakpoints?  Currently we get an error for non-existent resources, but there's no error if you try to clear a breakpoint on a resource where no breakpoint is set - perhaps we should just raise an exception in Resource.signal when handling the signal?'}, {'account_id': 9591, 'date': '2015-01-29 18:05:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Looks great! 
One observation:  a common debugging pattern is to stop at breakpoint A, check around, clear A, set another breakpoint B further down the path and continue to B, so on. Stepping is typically done this way in a high level debugger, where the debugger would have to parse the stack and figure out where the next resource is in the graph to set the next breakpoint. We can generalize the breakpoint support with something like:
   heat breakpoint-list mystack
   heat breakpoint-set  mystack new_breakpoint
   heat breakpoint-clear mystack old_breakpoint   (equivalent to clear-breakpoints)
This should also make the breakpoint feature more consistent with other features and help with usability.
This also implies that we allow adding new breakpoints to a stack that's already stopped at a breakpoint.  If the targeted resource has already been created, then the new breakpoint would have no effect, but if it has not been created, then the stack would stop at the new breakpoint."}, {'account_id': 4330, 'date': '2015-01-30 14:10:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Good points!

I modeled `clear-breakpoints` on signals, but it does make the interfaces inconsistent for no reason. I'll fix that syntax.

Agreed that we should show an error when we're clearing a breakpoint on a resource that doesn't have it.

And I do agree with Ton's proposed interface. It makes things more consistent (and we can keep the stack create/update syntax for convenience)."}, {'account_id': 3098, 'date': '2015-02-06 22:44:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

To make this work like breakpoints work in gdb, there needs to be another command in addition to the commands Ton suggested: heat breakpoint-continue. This command would make stack execution continue until the next breakpoint. Would allow finer control too, such as if you wanted to pause upon every instance in a resource group. (I think it's reasonable to only allow breakpoints to be set when stack execution is paused or not started.)

Otherwise, AFAICT you'd have to assume breakpoint-clear is an implicit continue."}, {'account_id': 9591, 'date': '2015-02-17 01:17:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

With the current implementation, clearing a breakpoint where a resource is spinning would be an implicit continue.  If the user wants to step to a new breakpoint, the user would need to make sure to set the new breakpoint before clearing the current breakpoint.  This is a little different from the typical user experience, but it's usable."}, {'account_id': 4330, 'date': '2015-02-19 15:16:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4330, 'date': '2015-02-19 15:17:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4330, 'date': '2015-02-19 15:22:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This revision makes the syntax for breakpoint-clear consistent with stack-create/stack-update and adds tests for breakpoint-clear.

There have been good suggestions here for additional CLI methods: breakpoint-set, breakpoint-list, running to completion (breakpoint-clear-all?) and stepping through (breakpoint-step).

Question is: how much of that should happen in this patch vs. followup patches? The code here works as a good foundation and I would prefer the remaining work happening in subsequent commits.

Would that work for everyone or should I put a subset of them here?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-02-19 16:36:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

(3 comments)

Question and a couple minor wording issues inline.

Regarding your question, I think you can have --breakpoint in this patch if then more specific cmd line options will be added such as --breakpoint-set and --breakpoint-list. Sounds like the names should be decided up front.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2015-02-25 21:24:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Overall looks good, a couple of minor things noted inline.

> Regarding your question, I think you can have --breakpoint in this patch if then more specific cmd line options will be added such as --breakpoint-set and --breakpoint-list. Sounds like the names should be decided up front.

I agree that the interfaces proposed here are fine, but I personally don't think we need to gate landing this patch on deciding every other interface name we may require in the future - it's probably best to land this increment, use it for a while, then work on the next logical step.

That said, here's my 0.02 anyway:

breakpoint-set sounds like it could be useful, but I wonder if it's any different from a patch update adding a breakpoint (when convergence allows concurrent updates)?

Similarly, breakpoint-clear-all seems like it could also be a stack-update where you don't pass any breakpoints?

But like I said, I'm personally +1 on just landing this before we spend too much time bikeshedding on the next step."}, {'account_id': 12606, 'date': '2015-02-25 23:21:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I wasn't very clear in my comment above, need to proofread better before hitting submit, sorry. What I meant to say is that at least the command to set a breakpoint should be decided before hand so that it does not need to change later. Doesn't matter if it is --breakpoint or --breakpoint-set (though I think the latter is a safer choice, since we know more breakpoint commands will be added added later on)."}, {'account_id': 4330, 'date': '2015-03-02 17:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4330, 'date': '2015-03-02 17:48:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-02 19:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

Question inline about using env['breakpoints'] to also pass cmd line breakpoints to the engine."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2015-03-03 10:24:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2015-03-03 10:26:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Question inline about using env['breakpoints'] to also pass cmd line breakpoints to the engine.

We definitely need to be careful of the interaction here, but I'm not sure that this approach presents a problem - the engine needs to store the current environment, and on a patch update, either use the existing environment, or patch in whatever environment is provided?

I've commented on the patch you referenced, as I'm not clear if the patches as posted for environment reuse work other than for the resource registry atm - probably we need a few functional tests to prove the various combinations of updates work as expected."}, {'account_id': 12606, 'date': '2015-03-03 15:50:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

My concern was related to the following scenario. Let's say you do a stack-create with an environment that just contains some custom resources. You also pass one or more breakpoints as cmd line arguments. Later when you do a stack-update you want to suppress the breakpoints, so you omit the --breakpoint arguments. You also want to reuse the old environment so you don't send a new one. In this situation it seems to me the engine will not be able to drop the breakpoints."}, {'account_id': 4330, 'date': '2015-03-06 13:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-06 14:52:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-22 15:35:02.000000000', 'message': 'Add options for setting and clearing of breakpoints

Breakpoints can be set on stack create / update:

    heat stack-create mystack -f mytemplate.yaml \
        --breakpoint SomeResource \
        --breakpoint SomeOtherResource \
        --breakpoint nested_stack/another_nested_stack/NestedResource

or within the environment:

    breakpoints:
    - SomeResource
    - SomeOtherResource
    - [nested_stack, another_nested_stack, NestedResource]

Breakpoints can be then cleared:

    heat clear-breakpoints mystack SomeResource SomeOtherResource

    # ID of the nested stack:
    heat clear-breakpoints 9120a9a2-d75c-4d94-b6f7-7746d60f2ed1 \
        NestedResource

Change-Id: I6b77f2895bada7b423fc47feb44cb87555d6afd8

or within the environment:

    - SomeResource

commit_message:
Add options for setting and clearing of hooks

Hooks can be set on stack create / update:

    heat stack-create mystack -f mytemplate.yaml \
        --pre-create SomeResource \
        --pre-create SomeOtherResource \
        --pre-create nested_stack/nested_2/NestedResource

or within the resource_registry section of the environment:

    resource_registry:
      resources:
        SomeResource:
          hooks: pre-create
        SomeOtherResource:
          hooks: pre-create
        nested_stack:
          nested_2:
            NestedResource:
              hooks: pre-create

Hooks can be then cleared:

    heat hook-clear --pre-create mystack SomeResource SomeOtherResource

    heat hook-clear --pre-create mystack nested_stack/nested_2/NestedResource

Change-Id: I6b77f2895bada7b423fc47feb44cb87555d6afd8

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-31 22:26:05.000000000', 'message': 'Special case nova network when constructing icehouse requested networks

The NetworkRequestList object renders tuples differently depending on
network manager. When falling back to older RPC APIs we are missing
the special casing for the nova network, causing things to blow
up during icehouse->juno partial upgrades when specifying a network
with during instance spawn.

Change-Id: I792f64aa5cbbe9666505d1c7958796c771d4aff2
Closes-bug: #1438920
(cherry picked from commit 9198a47843b8ea19eb80c7a50998cd06367851dc)
'}, {'created': '2015-03-31 22:35:23.000000000', 'message': 'Handle nova-network tuple format in legacy RPC calls

The NetworkRequestList object renders tuples differently depending on
network manager. When falling back to older RPC APIs we are missing
the special casing for the nova network, causing things to blow
up during icehouse->juno partial upgrades when specifying a network
with during instance spawn.

Change-Id: I792f64aa5cbbe9666505d1c7958796c771d4aff2
Closes-bug: #1438920
(cherry picked from commit 9198a47843b8ea19eb80c7a50998cd06367851dc)
'}]
commit_message:
Handle nova-network tuple format in legacy RPC calls

The NetworkRequestList object renders tuples differently depending on
network manager. When falling back to older RPC APIs we are missing
the special casing for the nova network, causing things to blow
up during icehouse->juno partial upgrades when specifying a network
with during instance spawn.

Change-Id: I792f64aa5cbbe9666505d1c7958796c771d4aff2
Closes-bug: #1438920
(cherry picked from commit 9198a47843b8ea19eb80c7a50998cd06367851dc)

commit_message:
change the floating_ips tables.py argument

the floating_ips tables.py use the argument 'volume = None',
it's a mistake, so change it to 'fip = None' as the argument

Change-Id: I4a2b3ecb0f227e699a61321a0dfd0aba0395c713

commit_message:
No need to clone tripleo-puppet-elements

We can drop the clone of tripleo-puppet-elements now
that we added it in the openstack-infra/project-config
project. See project-config patch here:
I8702e4cd9442fcef891af26b0dcd6cbf6c49bf8b

Change-Id: I8648d683aec37cb82dd6f15fea663246bfe511cf

[{'created': '2015-01-16 12:01:29.000000000', 'message': "Prevent unclustered RabbitMQ with 0 nodes

It can happen that RabbitMQ attempts to start before Heat has delivered
rabbit.nodes. It comes through as a blank value, IE with 0 nodes in it,
causing the Rabbit post-configure script to think we want a
non-clustered Rabbit config. This is not limited to one node - all nodes
will attempt to start non-clustered.

They can then start receiving messages, which makes joining a cluster
later difficult. To avoid this situation, first of all only allow the
bootstrap node to come up non-clustered. If you want a non-clustered
config you must have a single node control plane already so this is
fine.

Do not configure at all if we don't know who the bootstrap node is. Nor
should even the bootstrap node configure as non-clustered if we can see
other nodes are clustered.

Change-Id: Ib2ec261c84143640a5ccd1abbc99be1c8020c543

commit_message:
Prevent unclustered RabbitMQ with 0 nodes

It can happen that RabbitMQ attempts to start before Heat has delivered
rabbit.nodes. It comes through as a blank value, IE with 0 nodes in it,
causing the Rabbit post-configure script to think we want a
non-clustered Rabbit config. This is not limited to one node - all nodes
will attempt to start non-clustered.

They can then start receiving messages, which makes joining a cluster
later difficult. To avoid this situation, first of all only allow the
bootstrap node to come up non-clustered. If you want a non-clustered
config you must have a single node control plane already so this is
fine.

Do not configure at all if we don't know who the bootstrap node is. Nor
should even the bootstrap node configure as non-clustered if we can see
other nodes are clustered.

Change-Id: Ib2ec261c84143640a5ccd1abbc99be1c8020c543

[{'created': '2015-03-10 02:47:35.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid calling sudo just to change users

When running a command as a user != root, the previous code would wrap
the final command with an additional `sudo -u $user`.  Apart from being
heavyweight, using sudo here also resets permissions, etc preventing
related efforts to use more advanced privilege mechanisms (like Linux
capabilities or SELinux policies)

This change simply calls os.setuid() in the child process instead.

commit_message:
Avoid calling sudo just to change users

When running a command as a user != root, the previous code would wrap
the final command with an additional `sudo -u $user`.  Apart from being
heavyweight, using sudo here also resets permissions, etc preventing
related efforts to use more advanced privilege mechanisms (like Linux
capabilities or SELinux policies)

This change simply calls os.setuid() in the child process instead.

Change-Id: I3c4c21258d724a25c41a680ec7939869649269ed

Add API tests for subnetpool allocation

Add subnetpool creating, listing, updating and deleting
via REST API.

Change-Id: I0be397e6739a651ce1562137f9b03d0ca8739697

Partially-Implements: blueprint subnet-allocation

commit_message:
fix the wrong update logic of catalog kvs driver

The update logic of catalog objects in kvs driver is wrong. Currently,
it just overwrites the old one rather than update.

Change-Id: I9fa582a71e1ad9b6fa06e2ffbff1472aeb975a54
Closes-Bug: #1384112
(cherry picked from commit 211d008e4939326cc0e38ed1a9253fcffe01cb64)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-02-15 02:04:26.000000000', 'message': "Don't try to convert LDAP attributes to boolean

Currently, in the ldap2py function, attribute values are attempted
to be converted to python friendly types.

It attempts to convert an attribute to boolean first, then fallback
as string. Any attribute value that is equal to 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
are converted to boolean value.

Only 'enabled' attribute require this type of handling, and it is
already by enabled2py function. The additional handling on ldap2py
function should be removed.

Change-Id: Ifd1e91f98ae22a5e5f7b9b2ddbfddba156e16a6d
Closes-Bug: #1411478
(cherry picked from commit 5b82b8ab6fd181124b9fb0fdb5f8ab76ff715435)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't try to convert LDAP attributes to boolean

Currently, in the ldap2py function, attribute values are attempted
to be converted to python friendly types.

It attempts to convert an attribute to boolean first, then fallback
as string. Any attribute value that is equal to 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'
are converted to boolean value.

Only 'enabled' attribute require this type of handling, and it is
already by enabled2py function. The additional handling on ldap2py
function should be removed.

Change-Id: Ifd1e91f98ae22a5e5f7b9b2ddbfddba156e16a6d
Closes-Bug: #1411478
(cherry picked from commit 5b82b8ab6fd181124b9fb0fdb5f8ab76ff715435)

commit_message:
do parameter check before updating endpoint_group

Currently, the update method of endpoint_group does parameter check
after updating endpoint_group. This leads to a bug that invalid data
will be updated successfully although api returns 400.

Change-Id: I94c0034a7bed2fe5b6f183ae8ef8d82cba512344
Closes-Bug: #1408930
(cherry picked from commit 663411b8e4f2333086335cadd651c05f2e4a9134)

Ian, that are rebases of other patches in this chain: every rebase of subsequent patch makes a new patchset in all of its dependencies, but that's not actual contribution. 
This patch is only made by me and Ina, and the https://review.openstack.org/#/c/148588/ is by Ina only, regardless of the patchset history: all of us were doing manual rebases of Domain and REST API changes, and this caused new patchsets here."}, {'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2015-03-31 16:25:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 105:

@Ian. Yes, Alex is right, all of those patchsets were just rebases. You can check it manually, but, trust me, there is no a single line of code from me. As well as in Mixin patch.

'}, {'created': '2015-03-06 13:19:30.000000000', 'message': "Artifact Plugins Loader

Adds a Stevedore-based plugin loader which is capable to load custom
Artifact Types implemented as classes or lists of classes.

The Loader validates if entry-points' names match the type names of the
ArtifactTypes, ensures that no version conflicts occur (i.e. there are
no Artifact Types which have identical combination of Type Name and Type
Version), maintains the mapping of Type Names to the actual classes and
also keeps an index of Artifact Types by their endpoint aliases.

Modifies the Serialization utility of Declarative framework to use the
actual set of plugins instead of synthetic type disctionary.

Adds several example plugins to glance/contrib directory.

Implements-blueprint: artifact-repository

Co-Authored-By: Inessa Vasilevskaya <ivasilevskaya@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alexander Tivelkov <ativelkov@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I5ff5d4c257a1c42885068f4343f52e55189265a5

The Loader validates if entry-points' names match the type names of the
ArtifactTypes, ensures that no version conflicts occur (i.e. there are
no Artifact Types which have identical combination of Type Name and Type
Version), maintains the mapping of Type Names to the actual classes and
also keeps an index of Artifact Types by their endpoint aliases.

Modifies the Serialization utility of Declarative framework to use the
actual set of plugins instead of synthetic type dictionary.

Adds several example plugins to glance/contrib directory.

Implements-blueprint: artifact-repository

Co-Authored-By: Inessa Vasilevskaya <ivasilevskaya@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alexander Tivelkov <ativelkov@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I5ff5d4c257a1c42885068f4343f52e55189265a5

commit_message:
Artifact Plugins Loader

Adds a Stevedore-based plugin loader which is capable to load custom
Artifact Types implemented as classes or lists of classes.

The Loader validates if entry-points' names match the type names of the
ArtifactTypes, ensures that no version conflicts occur (i.e. there are
no Artifact Types which have identical combination of Type Name and Type
Version), maintains the mapping of Type Names to the actual classes and
also keeps an index of Artifact Types by their endpoint aliases.

Modifies the Serialization utility of Declarative framework to use the
actual set of plugins instead of synthetic type dictionary.

Adds several example plugins to glance/contrib directory.

Implements-blueprint: artifact-repository

Co-Authored-By: Inessa Vasilevskaya <ivasilevskaya@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alexander Tivelkov <ativelkov@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I5ff5d4c257a1c42885068f4343f52e55189265a5

commit_message:
Policy creation and deletion in Horizon

Committing all related code here for safekeeping. Will begin splitting it out
into smaller patches as they are ready for review.

TODO:
- Rearrange elements to fit revised workflow (reverse steps, combine elements).
- Save rule from user input.
- Combine policy and plugin data source tables into one list.
- Change tables datalist to autcomplete combo box.
- Input mechanism for table self joins.
- Error handling when auth has expired.
- See if there's a way not to have CSS and JavaScript directly in the
  templates. Since we're using an existing dashboard, there could be issues
  using the Horizon customization framework if the user has existing
  customization files.

Change-Id: Ia6a103e8d1fed13ad5a43d8032682a749bd68895
Implements: blueprint horizon-create-policies

[{'created': '2015-03-31 14:05:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix post-start notify exit code for rabbit OCF

There is an error in OCF logic causing the resource to be reported
as $OCF_NOT_RUNNING that leads to additional restarts for rabbitmq
resources in pacemaker.

The solution is to ensure that only the node which actually has
started and is joining the cluster may fail with this error code,
while the other nodes may not.

Closes-bug: #1438699

Change-Id: I8d3b6e8f76a6a89608e59a52081c21931e5654fb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
'}, {'created': '2015-04-01 07:29:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix post-start notify exit code for rabbit OCF

There is an error in OCF logic causing the resource to be reported
as $OCF_NOT_RUNNING that leads to additional restarts for rabbitmq
resources in pacemaker.

The solution is to ensure that only the node which actually has
started and is joining the cluster may fail with this error code,
while the other nodes may not.

Closes-bug: #1438699

Change-Id: I8d3b6e8f76a6a89608e59a52081c21931e5654fb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix post-start notify exit code for rabbit OCF

There is an error in OCF logic causing the resource to be reported
as $OCF_NOT_RUNNING that leads to additional restarts for rabbitmq
resources in pacemaker.

The solution is to ensure that only the node which actually has
started and is joining the cluster may fail with this error code,
while the other nodes may not.

Closes-bug: #1438699

Change-Id: I8d3b6e8f76a6a89608e59a52081c21931e5654fb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Add websockets to our test suite

The base classes to test websockets were added but no tests were present
in the actual test suite. This patch adds the required packages, modules
and imports for that to work.

Change-Id: I2f3b222657555607133f7ccdb51914cf07248dc8
Partial-Implements: blueprint persistent-transport

commit_message:
Allow check_for_* functions to be consumed by wait_for

In order for the `check_for_*` functions to be consumed by `wait_for`,
they should notify of their success but not exit.

As a consequence, the previous behavior is restored by the fail_unless_*
companion functions.

With this change, it is now possible to do:

    wait_for 30 1 check_for_os_service_running keystone

Change-Id: I16ddf8913027030c3ccb5487713d172904508fd6

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-20 14:58:21.000000000', 'message': 'Deal with PEP-0476 certificate chaining checking

PEP-0476 introduced more thorough certificate chain verfication
for HTTPS connectivity; this was introduced in Python 2.7.9, and
breaks a number of unit tests in the cinder codebase.

Disable certificate chain verification for cinder SSL tests
using the backwards compatible SSLContext provided for this
purpose.

Change-Id: Iffc3658196f608c7a7c9b6527dc8e7210fb05bff
Closes-Bug: #1403068
(cherry picked from commit 4e849ef5fbb7159276435ac6f7315bf20274768d)
'}]
commit_message:
Deal with PEP-0476 certificate chaining checking

PEP-0476 introduced more thorough certificate chain verfication
for HTTPS connectivity; this was introduced in Python 2.7.9, and
breaks a number of unit tests in the cinder codebase.

Disable certificate chain verification for cinder SSL tests
using the backwards compatible SSLContext provided for this
purpose.

Change-Id: Iffc3658196f608c7a7c9b6527dc8e7210fb05bff
Closes-Bug: #1403068
(cherry picked from commit 4e849ef5fbb7159276435ac6f7315bf20274768d)

Fix reference to non-existent setup_dvr_flows_on_integ_tun_br

Found via the pylint no-member check.

Co-authored-by: Kevin Benton <blak111@gmail.com>

Closes-Bug: #1423775
Change-Id: Id4104fa783aa8c34917df6d16ff1290882f93af5

[{'created': '2015-02-18 11:22:04.000000000', 'message': 'Search in /sys/class/net for network devices

When using /sys/devices/net/virtual to search for tap devices, not all
devices are listed there (i.e. when using Xen).
Also according to the Linux kernel documentation (see
ABI/testing/sysfs-devices), /sys/class should be used
instead of /sys/devices.

Change-Id: I9b4981332b66b6d3f9c36511c81432d3e7644bdd
Closes-Bug: #1419754
(cherry picked from commit e228a3dc69eca08896c4e22d6a2d51b60a9a0a94)
'}]
commit_message:
Search in /sys/class/net for network devices

When using /sys/devices/net/virtual to search for tap devices, not all
devices are listed there (i.e. when using Xen).
Also according to the Linux kernel documentation (see
ABI/testing/sysfs-devices), /sys/class should be used
instead of /sys/devices.

Change-Id: I9b4981332b66b6d3f9c36511c81432d3e7644bdd
Closes-Bug: #1419754
(cherry picked from commit e228a3dc69eca08896c4e22d6a2d51b60a9a0a94)

commit_message:
WIP - Enable Karma as an independent build.

A WIP patch with the horizon team's javascript testers. Does the following:

- Adds npm-install as a macro builder.

Change-Id: I5f54e5aa9f1c4c4d683666888a90a60aedfb1ea0

commit_message:
Refactor logging in loop to only log debug messages once

Logging entries in a loop to a file can be expensive for a large
number of objects (e.g. ports) in a loop. Rather than perform the
overhead of logging a debug entry for each line within the hosts
file, move the debug trace of the contents to after the loop to
bulk up the I/O operations.

Conflicts:
        neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py

(cherry-picked from d93e0098ebd5f333d6f496f10a663cd4351410ae)
Change-Id: I3ad7864eeb2f959549ed356a1e34fa18804395cc
Closes-Bug: #1414218

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-30 21:15:23.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor deploy ramdisk to allow use of targetcli

RHEL 7 does not ship tgtadm or tgtd so they cannot be used in the
deploy ramdisk.  This change separates the tgt-specific parts of
the ramdisk into their own element, and adds a new one that supports
targetcli instead.

For now, the tgt implementation can only be used with traditional
busybox ramdisks and the targetcli one can only be used with dracut.
This is because dracut is primarily used for RHEL right now so it
makes sense to keep the dependencies simple.  If there is a future
desire to mix and match the implementations that could be done, but
it would require users to explicitly select between tgt and
targetcli.

Change-Id: I4f99c91016287e08d836095c2f2261de8b45abdc
Co-Authored-By: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Refactor deploy ramdisk to allow use of targetcli

RHEL 7 does not ship tgtadm or tgtd so they cannot be used in the
deploy ramdisk.  This change separates the tgt-specific parts of
the ramdisk into their own element, and adds a new one that supports
targetcli instead.

For now, the tgt implementation can only be used with traditional
busybox ramdisks and the targetcli one can only be used with dracut.
This is because dracut is primarily used for RHEL right now so it
makes sense to keep the dependencies simple.  If there is a future
desire to mix and match the implementations that could be done, but
it would require users to explicitly select between tgt and
targetcli.

Change-Id: I4f99c91016287e08d836095c2f2261de8b45abdc
Co-Authored-By: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-02-25 12:54:02.000000000', 'message': "Improve exception handling in _process_router_update()

in _process_router_update() where _process_routers() method is
called no exception is handled. In case any (intermittent)
exception happens inside _process_routers() (e.g. MessagingTimeout
on fetching external net from server) it results in a situation
where agent completely forgets about the router and continues
working as usual while server shows router hosted by agent.

This patch adds exception handler there and set fullsync = True
like it's done earlier in _process_router_update() when getting
routers from server.

Change-Id: I5bfc540a926349848702100744f97c597b852604
Closes-Bug: #1423571
(cherry picked from commit 4f55c8f689861631a8060e9918066792f56dfcf5)
"}]
commit_message:
Improve exception handling in _process_router_update()

in _process_router_update() where _process_routers() method is
called no exception is handled. In case any (intermittent)
exception happens inside _process_routers() (e.g. MessagingTimeout
on fetching external net from server) it results in a situation
where agent completely forgets about the router and continues
working as usual while server shows router hosted by agent.

This patch adds exception handler there and set fullsync = True
like it's done earlier in _process_router_update() when getting
routers from server.

Change-Id: I5bfc540a926349848702100744f97c597b852604
Closes-Bug: #1423571
(cherry picked from commit 4f55c8f689861631a8060e9918066792f56dfcf5)

This commit adds a new repo, os-testr. The intent of this repo is to
provide tooling to interact and use testr. Right now it contains 2
pieces subunit-trace, which has become the de-facto output filter for
running tests, and ostestr which is a testr wrapper similar to the
pretty_tox.sh scripts which are currently used everywhere but expands
on that functionality.

commit_message:
Add os-testr repo

This commit adds a new repo, os-testr. The intent of this repo is to
provide tooling to interact and use testr. Right now it contains 2
pieces subunit-trace, which has become the de-facto output filter for
running tests, and ostestr which is a testr wrapper similar to the
pretty_tox.sh scripts which are currently used everywhere but expands
on that functionality.

Change-Id: I994b1271b69741161d1ce165eda4ae32d529bdc4
Depends-On: Idbd6251546809f6ea7a651be9e758619fddd4e7f

commit_message:
gridfs: add pymongo to test-requirements and update tests

pymongo is an optional requirement for glance_store if you're not using
the gridfs backend, but for tests we should have it in
test-requirements.txt with other optional backend dependencies like boto
for s3 and oslo.vmware for the vmware backend.

This adds pymongo to test-requirements.txt and removes the conditional
imports and skips in the gridfs tests.

Change-Id: I9332fc5b27e35ed6194eedf5ccd1586c3ba9096e

commit_message:
Update the deprecated group/name to Kilo release

For Kilo release, there are many deprecated group/name in conf files of openstack,
so we need to change the deprecated group/name to new group/name.

blueprint conf-section-update-for-kilo
Closes-bug: #1436170

Change-Id: Iaacbab4c1d92b57ac7a080c5bf4539138387f4c8

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-02-05 10:22:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix extra-dhcp-opt on stateless dhcpv6 subnet

The opts in dnsmasq opt-file is depending on the tag set
in the host-file. When you have only one stateless dhcpv6 subnet,
it will be filtered by the _iter_host() function, and will not be
written to the host-file, this may lead to extra-dhcp-opt not working.

Closes-Bug:#1411137

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py
	neutron/tests/unit/test_linux_dhcp.py

Change-Id: Ieed16280fb3c4c91f7d906c0410446d2a112b93e
(cherry picked from commit a584e35775391a2a93535482c5a05ff8774cb56b)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix extra-dhcp-opt on stateless dhcpv6 subnet

The opts in dnsmasq opt-file is depending on the tag set
in the host-file. When you have only one stateless dhcpv6 subnet,
it will be filtered by the _iter_host() function, and will not be
written to the host-file, this may lead to extra-dhcp-opt not working.

Closes-Bug:#1411137

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py
	neutron/tests/unit/test_linux_dhcp.py

Change-Id: Ieed16280fb3c4c91f7d906c0410446d2a112b93e
(cherry picked from commit a584e35775391a2a93535482c5a05ff8774cb56b)

commit_message:
Add system test for DualHypervisors mode(vCenter) with CephOSD

Scenario:
1. Create cluster with vCenter support
2. Configure CephOSD as backend for Glance and Cinder
3. Add 3 nodes with Controller+CephOSD roles
4. Add 2 nodes with compute role
6. Deploy the cluster
7. Run network verification
8. Run OSTF

Change-Id: I39dba9585dbdf52d32f55b0914b2d1549812d730
Closes-bug: #1439274

commit_message:
Avoid MODULEPATH environment var in config generator

MODULEPATH is apparently a well known variable from
environment-modules package. So let's just use another
one as we don't care about the specific var name itself.

Closes-Bug: #1437904
Change-Id: Id79bbdaad498c771dc4c032256bd8160b5663ef9

commit_message:
Catch PortNotFound and SubnetNotFound during network_delete

In some cases PortNotFound exception during network_delete
could be caused by concurrent port deletion by DHCP agent.
This condition should not prevent network from deleting.

(cherry picked from 8479921e111e1c306db76c52b33115cc5a77c420)

Change-Id: Ie6eae4cecb64120c41de9823d9e72066094ad2ce
Closes-Bug: #1405197

commit_message:
Use python3 for fuel_logs.py to support XZ compression for tarfile

- set python3 as an interpretator
- add '.decode()' to convert strings from 'binary' mode for python3

Change-Id: I92fe5fcee471af44e2c0bad3bf437480f12df703
Closes-Bug: #1439135

commit_message:
Update periodic sync defaults

By default, we sync all zones changed in the last 6 hours, every
30 minutes.

Change-Id: Ie5470833691bda10128a19c4b980f86e7c1dd5b3

I think that this is a very good start. I have tested the code and works above. This will make the move to the ovn db interface far quicker'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2015-03-30 14:55:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

I'm really curious what Terry Wilson thinks about this, since he did the similar work in Neutron.

One thing that's different about this driver is that it's really not important to maintain any support for using ovn-nbctl.  So, if that's the case, I'm curious if Terry would have designed things differently to make ovsdb support easier."}, {'account_id': 11343, 'date': '2015-03-30 15:19:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

I added Terry here to get his feedback for that reason.

I do think however that the API part is pretty simple, the use of transactions is of course important to any kind of backend DB implementation (or CLI)

Hopefully we can leverage Terry's work for the backend implementation, but anyhow with this we won't need to change any of the drivers logic."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2015-04-01 14:46:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

I think this is good for now.  If later we decide the abstraction isn't necessary when we're doing native ovsdb only, we can adapt.  Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2015-04-01 15:09:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Sorry for showing up late on this one. Basically, there has to be some abstraction between OVSDB/python IDL library because it is so non-trivial to use. This abstraction mostly makes sense, as long as we don't keep the nbctl version after code is written that actually groups multiple operations into a single transaction (unless nbctl evolves to support transactions just like ovs-vsctl)."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2015-04-01 19:52:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Russell's idea for a comment about the lack of transactional nature would make sense as a follow on, but this looks good now. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-01 19:52:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: -Verified

commit_message:
Add OVSDB abstraction between API and implementation

Add an abstraction between the API and the way used
to communicate with OVN.
Seperate the implementation to CLI and OVSDB.

Code is taken and is similar to the current OVS_LIB implementation
in order to combine the two code bases in the future

Change-Id: I4f90af517d8760054aad3ec67a63624ed0cec55f

commit_message:
Adding value_meta to certain metrics

The value_meta parameter was recently added to the
monasca-api.  This allows the addition of meta-information
to be sent with any metrics that are sent from the agent.
value_meta was added for the http_status, nagios_wrapper,
and host_alive checks in the agent.  Also, consolidated
some of the duplicate exception handling and reformatted
some code blocks.

Change-Id: I3d9e9a8e54cd2582bde47c7c128a3788b821c156

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Per-policy DiskFile classes

Adds specific disk file classes for EC policy types.

The new ECDiskFile and ECDiskFileWriter classes are used
by the ECDiskFileManager.

ECDiskFileManager is registered with the DiskFileRouter for
use with EC_POLICY type policies.

Change-Id: I22f915160dc67a9e18f4738c1ddf068344e8ad5d

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-01 04:53:24.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for policy types, 'erasure_coding' policy

This patch extends the StoragePolicy class for non-replication storage
policies, the first one being "erasure coding".

Changes:

 - Add 'policy_type' support to BaseStoragePolicy class
 - Disallow direct instatiation of BaseStoragePolicy class

 - Subclass BaseStoragePolicy

   - "StoragePolicy":
     . Replication policy, default
     . policy_type = 'replication'

   - "ECStoragePolicy":
     . Erasure Coding policy
     . policy_type = 'erasure_coding'
     . Private member variables
       ec_type (EC backend),
       ec_num_data_fragments (number of fragments original
         data split into after erasure coding operation),
       ec_num_parity_fragments (number of parity fragments
       generated during erasure coding)
     . Private methods
       EC specific metadata and ring validator methods.

 - Swift will use PyECLib, a Python Erasure Coding library,
   for erasure coding operations. This patch adds PyECLib to
   Swift requirements.txt. PyECLib is already an approved
   OpenStack core requirement.
   (https://bitbucket.org/kmgreen2/pyeclib/)

 - Add test cases for
   - 'policy_type' StoragePolicy member
   - policy_type == 'erasure_coding'

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ie0e09796e3ec45d3e656fb7540d0e5a5709b8386
